member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.IdentityType
member.summary: Defines identifiers for types of entities identity provided by the Telerik Data Access.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.IdentityType.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the default value for the identity type will be used by the runtime.
member.remarks: The runtime might calculate this value on a later stage depending on the other settings of the meta model or the specific backend used.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.IdentityType.Internal
member.summary: Specifies that the identity is managed internally for the type by Telerik Data Access and it is not visible as a field in the type.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.IdentityType.SingleField
member.summary: Specifies that a single field in the respective type will hold the identity information.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.IdentityType.MultipleField
member.summary: Specifies that a multiple fields in the respective type will hold the identity information. Also one needs to provide a class that implements the IOblectId and manages the identity information.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.InheritanceStrategy
member.summary: Defines identifiers for types of inheritance provided by the Telerik Data Access.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.InheritanceStrategy.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the default value for the inheritance strategy will be used by the runtime.
member.remarks: The runtime might calculate this value on a later stage depending on the other settings of the meta model or the specific backend used.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.InheritanceStrategy.Flat
member.summary: Defines an inheritance strategy where all classes share a single table. Discriminator column is required for the complete definition.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.InheritanceStrategy.Vertical
member.summary: Defines an inheritance strategy where each type has its own table. The table contains only the members defined for the respective type. The root base type table must contain a discriminator column.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.InheritanceStrategy.Horizontal
member.summary: Defines an inheritance strategy where each type has its own table. As the base types should be abstract, they will not have tables mapped to them and every concrete type will have columns that contain base class fields information.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.ITableDescriptor
member.summary: Contains a description of a mapped table .
member.remarks: The returned description provides access to the information as present in the current mapping.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.ITableDescriptor.Name
member.summary: Gets the complete name of the table in delimited form.

remarks.para: The complete name includes the schema name in delimeted form, e.g. [My Schema].[My Table] .
The delimited form can be different between various backends.

member.value: Delimited name of the column

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer
member.summary: On the conceptual level, the MetaDataContainer class represents a container that will be mapped to a database object in the storage. The MetaDataContainer class can describe all persisant storage artifacts like tables, views, stored procedures, indexes, constraints, etc. It also can describe all conceptual level artifacts like classes, properties, fields, relationships, etc.

member.returns: The attribute.

member.returns: The value of the attribute.

member.summary: Clones this meta item.
member.returns: A cloned instance of this meta item.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.CompareCore(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares the current meta item with another meta item of the same type and returns an integer that indicates whether the current instance precedes, follows, or occurs in the same position in the sort order as the other meta item.
member.param: An object to compare with this instance.
member.returns: A value that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.GetContainerIdentifier
member.summary: Computes hash code identifying the object based on the PersistentTypes names

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.PersistentTypes
member.summary: Gets a list of types that are mapped to the corresponding artifacts like tables available in the relational store.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.Associations
member.summary: Gets a list of associations that connect pairs of persistent types.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.Tables
member.summary: Gets a list of tables that are available in the current container instance.
member.remarks: During runtime the Tables collection contains both Tables and Views, because the Telerik Data Access runtime treats them in the same way.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.Views
member.summary: Gets a list of views that are available in the current container instance.
member.remarks: During runtime the Views collection will be empty.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.Constraints
member.summary: Gets a list of constraints that are available in the current container instance.
member.remarks: If the information inside the current container instance is populated by an already mapped model, it will contain only the constraints that are involved in the actual model (not all available in the relational store).

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.Indexes
member.summary: Gets a list of indexes that are available in the current container instance.
member.remarks: If the information inside the current container instance is populated by an already mapped model, it will contain only the indexes that are involved in the actual model (not all available in the relational store).

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.StoredProcedures
member.summary: Gets a list of stored procedures that are available in the current container instance.
member.remarks: If the information inside the current container instance is populated by an already mapped model, it will contain only the stored procedures that are auto-generated for CUD operations related to the model (the reverse-mapped procedures are directly generated as static instances on a static class and they are not contained currently in the collection.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.Schemas
member.summary: Gets a list of schema names that are available in the current container instance.
member.remarks: If the information inside the current container instance is populated by an already mapped model, it will contain only the schema names that are involved in the actual model (not all available in the relational store).

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.Interfaces
member.summary: Gets a list of persistent interfaces that can be implemented by some of the persistent types that are part of the current container instance

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.Structs
member.summary: Gets a list of persistent structs that can be referenced by some of the persistent types that are part of the current container instance

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.UserDefinedTypes
member.summary: Gets a list of user defined types in the database.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer.DefaultMapping
member.summary: Gets the default mapping. This is used for all non specified settings at the mapping nodes.

member.summary: Controls the max length in characters for a table name.

member.summary: Controls the max length in characters for a column name.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.PKFieldSuffix
member.summary: Controls the suffix added to table or field names to name primary key columns. The default is _id so the pk for the employee table will be employee_id.

member.summary: Controls the max length in characters for a constraint name.

member.summary: Controls the max length in characters for an index name.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.MaxProcedureNameLength
member.summary: Controls the max length in characters for a procedure name.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.PKConstraintNamePrefix
member.summary: Controls the prefix added to a table name to generate its primary key constraint name.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.FKConstraintNamePrefix
member.summary: Set the prefix added to a reference constraint name.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.WordBreak
member.summary: Controls the string used to break 'words' when generating names from field and class names and so on.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.SequenceColumnName
member.summary: Cnotrols the name used for sequence columns in link tables. These are used to preserve the order of elements in ordered collections (lists and arrays).

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.ValueColumnName
member.summary: Controls the name used for value columns in link tables where the values are not references to PC instances.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.KeyColumnName
member.summary: Controls the name used for keys columns in link tables for maps where the keys are not references to PC instances.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.DiscriminatorColumnName
member.summary: Controls the name used for classId columns. These are added to the table for the base class in an inheritance hierarchy.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.IndexNamePrefix
member.summary: Controls the prefix used to generate index names.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.UseModelNames
member.summary: Controls whether shortened/mangled names are to be used for tables and columns or if model names (class names, field names) are to be used.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNameGenerator.PolyRefDiscriminatorColumnSuffix
member.summary: Controls the string appended for polymorphic reference class id columns.

member.summary: Controls whether duplicate names are disambiguated by appending an unique number.

member.summary: Controls whether duplicate join table names are disambiguated by appending an unique number.

member.summary: Controls whether duplicate constraint names are disambiguated by appending an unique number.

member.summary: Controls if non-standard characters like '/' are replaced even when model names are used.

member.summary: Gets the information whether the current type represents the 'master role' end of a association.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNavigationMember.IsManaged
member.summary: Gets whether association's end integrity is managed by Telerik Data Access.
member.remarks: It is important that one-to-many and many-to-many relationships are consistent in your model. If one side of the relationship is out of sync with the other side then either the database will not be updated properly or stale data will be left in the 2nd level cache. If you are using managed relationships then this is usually taken care of by Telerik Data Access. If you are using unmanaged relationships then you must handle this in your code.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNavigationMember.IsDependent
member.summary: Gets whether the state of association's end that the current member represents is dependent on the operations applied on the corresponding end of the association. It allows operations like cascading deletes to be executed.
member.remarks: Cascading deletes are disabled by default and are only enabled for references specified as dependent, by adding the [OpenAccess.Depend] attribute to the referenced persistent class.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetaNavigationMember.OrderBy
member.summary: Gets or sets the 'OrderBy' expression used in the SQL query when obtaining the records that are part of a collection.

member.summary: Gets the key type of the member if this member represents a dictionary field.

member.summary: Gets the .Net runtime type
member.remarks: This property will have a value of null during design time.

member.summary: Specifies that an exception will be raised when a field has null value assigned

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.OptimisticConcurrencyControlStrategy
member.summary: Specifies the concurrency control options for the persistent types in the Telerik Data Access meta model.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.OptimisticConcurrencyControlStrategy.Default
member.summary: Defines that the default value for the optimistic concurrency control strategy will be used by the runtime.
member.remarks: The runtime might calculate this value on a later stage depending on the other settings of the meta model or the specific backend used.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.OptimisticConcurrencyControlStrategy.None
member.summary: Defines that no concurrency checks will be done on the database server.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.OptimisticConcurrencyControlStrategy.Version
member.summary: Defines that a version column is used to detect concurrent updates. The version number is incremented on every update and the previous version number is included in the where clause. This is the fastest and safest optimistic concurrency control mode. This is the default and suggested concurrency mode.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.OptimisticConcurrencyControlStrategy.Timestamp
member.summary: Defines that a timestamp column is to be used to detect concurrent updates. The timestamp is set on every update and the previous value is included in the where clause. This may not be safe if updates happen quicker than the resolution of the timestamp field. It is included to support legacy database schemas.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.OptimisticConcurrencyControlStrategy.Changed
member.summary: Defines that previous values of all changed columns will be included in the where clause. This provides more fine-grained optimistic concurrency control as different transactions may modify different fields of the same instance. This mode can be used when the database schema allows no modifications (adding a version column for example). Float and double fields are excluded as they are not exact (rounding procedures are different across databases and also differ from the way .NET is handling it).

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.OptimisticConcurrencyControlStrategy.Backend
member.summary: Defines that a backend specific concurrency control mechanism is used.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.OptimisticConcurrencyControlStrategy.All
member.summary: Defines that the values of all columns (changed or not) will be included in the where clause.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.CacheStrategy
member.summary: Describes the strategy for the database level cache

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.CacheStrategy.Default
member.summary: Specifies that the default value for the cache strategy will be used by the runtime.
member.remarks: The runtime might calculate this value on a later stage depending on the other settings of the meta model or the specific backend used.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.CacheStrategy.No
member.summary: Do not cache instances of this class.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.CacheStrategy.Yes
member.summary: Cache instances of this class.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.CacheStrategy.All
member.summary: Cache all instances of this class as soon as an instance is requested. All rows from its table will be read and cached whenever an instance is requested but not found in cache. This may work well for small static tables when using a big cache.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.SchemaReadParameters
member.summary: Controls the behavior of the SchemaReader.GetSchema method.
member.remarks: Use this class to filter the objects to be retrieved. All schema objects are retrieved by default. Tables and view are always fetched or omitted together. It is curently not possible to fetch only 1 type and not the other. The 'Constraints' and 'Indexes' properties are used only if the 'TablesAndViews' is set to true i.e constraints and indexes are fetched together only with tables and not independently.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKey.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns a value that indicates whether this instance is equal to a specified ObjectKey.
member.remarks: Two ObjectKeys are considered equal if their refers to the same persistent type and the key and version values are equal. The order of they key and version members is not considered.
member.param: An object to compare with this instance.
member.returns: true if this instance and 'other' have equal values; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKey.Create(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates an ObjectKey instance from a given persistent entity
member.remarks: The parameter should be persistence capable and should be managed by an OpenAccessContext instance. The returned ObjectKey does not have version information. In order to obtain a key with version information use the method.
member.param: Persistent entity whose ObjectKey instance is to be created
member.returns: ObjectKey instance representing the identity information of the parameter
member.exception: is a null reference
is not managed by a context

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKey.CreateWithVersion(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates an ObjectKey instance with version information, from a given persistent entity.
member.remarks: The parameter should be persistence capable and should be managed by an OpenAccessContext instance. The returned ObjectKey contains version information for the specified entity. The version information consists of key/value pairs for each field that is used to perform optimistic concurrency checks. If the type of the persistent entity uses the the returned ObjectKey does not contain any version information. No version information is returned for a new entity that is added to a context but not yet committed to the database via call to . Similarly no version information is returned for an entity that is removed from the context via .
member.param: Persistent entity whose ObjectKey is to be created
member.returns: ObjectKey instance representing the identity and version information of the parameter
member.exception: is a null reference
is not managed by a context

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKey.GetWithoutVersion
member.summary: Returns a copy of the current ObjectKey instance but without any version information
member.returns: An ObjectKey instance that is a copy of the current instance but has no version information.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKeyMember
member.summary: Represents a key name and value pair that is part of an ObjectKey.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKeyMember.UnspecifiedKeyName
member.summary: Represents a key without a name.
member.remarks: This member can be used as the name of a key for persistent types whose identity is made up of a single primitive member. It is not required to explicitly specify the key name in such cases as this information can be easily inferred. If you want construct an ObjectKey by specifying just the persistent type name and the key value, you can use the .

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKeyMember.InternalIdentityField
member.summary: Represents a identity member that is managed internally by Telerik Data Access and does not have a corresponding primitive member declared in the persistent type.
member.remarks: An ObjectKeyMember instance with a key name 'InternalIdentityField' indicates that the identity member for the it's persistent type is managed internally by Telerik Data Access.The persistent type does not have a field or property declared explicitly within code.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKeyMember.InternalVersionField
member.summary: Represents a primitive member used for optimistic concurrency checks that is managed internally by Telerik Data Access and does not have a corresponding primitive member declared in the persistent type.
member.remarks: An ObjectVersionMember instance with a key name 'InternalVersionField' indicates that the version member for the it's persistent type is managed internally by Telerik Data Access.The persistent type does not have a field or property declared explicitly within code.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase
member.summary: OpenAccess context base class for .NET 2.0 usage.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.IOpenAccessContextOptions
member.summary: Defines options that affect the behavior of the OpenAccessContextBase.

remarks.para: Instances of this class can be obtained from the property, which will always contain the current context options of the .

members.member:
Gets or sets a Boolean value that determines whether the context behaves in data synchronization mode during Insert and Update operations. If the OpenAccessContextBase is in this mode, OpenAccess will skip calculation of the DateTime and version field values.
This property should be set to 'True' only if the context instance is used to synchronize the data between two databases. In such a scenario it is desired that the auto calculated fields such as the 'version' field are not recalculated since an exact copy of the data should be inserted in the target database.
Do not set this property to 'True' for a context that is used for normal operations. If set, it could lead to undesired database exceptions due to the default value of the field being inserted or updated.
/// A value that is true when data synchronization mode is enabled; otherwise false.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IOpenAccessContextOptions.MaintainOriginalValues
member.summary: Controls weather the original values are loaded and kept when a field is changed.
member.remarks: MaintainOriginalValues has to set to true if the original values have to be available. The memory consumption might increase per persistent object.
member.value: True if all original values should be kept in memory, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IOpenAccessContextOptions.RefreshObjectsAfterSaveChanges
member.summary: Controls weather all loaded objects are refreshed in a new transaction.
member.remarks:
If SaveChanges() or ClearChanges() is called, the data in the loaded objects managed by the context might no longer reflect the database content. Other processes or clients might have modified data in the database as well. To make the optimistic concurrency control working better, Telerik Data Access reloads all data in a subsequent transaction.
The default is true, and this setting should only be changed with great care, as setting it to false might result in long-living stale objects.
Note, that the default value of true does not guarantee non-stale objects when using optimistic transactions. It does only guarantee, that objects used in previous transactions are refreshed on the first read access in subsequent transactions of the same context.
member.value: True if all objects should be refreshed in subsequent transactions, false otherwise. True is the default.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IOpenAccessContextOptions.IsolationLevel
member.summary: Controls the isolation level of this contexts resources.
member.remarks:
When an isolation level is specified, the context will need to use transactions for read access.
When null is specified, the default isolation level (ReadCommitted) is used and transactions around read requests might be omitted (depending on the setting).
Not all database systems support all possible isolation levels, therefore only Snapshot, ReadCommitted and ReadUncommitted are currently supported.
The second level cache will not be used or populated when any value except null is specified for this context.
member.value: Isolation Level (Default: null)
member.exception: Wrong isolation level, only Snapshot, ReadCommitted and ReadUncommitted allowed.
Isolation level cannot be changed because a connection is active.

member.summary: Saves all changes in the context
member.remarks: If a current transaction is available it is used. If not the changes are committed immediately.

member.summary: Saves the changes with the specified concurrency mode
member.remarks: If all failures during commit should be collected and not only the first one the mode has to be used. This can be time consuming.
member.param: Mode to use

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.ClearChanges
member.summary: Rolls back all changes in the context
member.remarks: All changes made so far in this context are rolled back.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.FlushChanges
member.summary: Flushes all current changes to the database but keeps the transaction running.
member.remarks:
All changes made so far in this context are sent to the server but the transaction is not committed. A following SaveChanges or ClearChanges is necessary to complete the operations. Flush can be used to see all changed information in the following queries or to get the server side calculated primary keys immediately.
FlushChanges will pin a database connection to the context, start a server side transaction and keeps that running until ClearChanges or SaveChanges is called. The time between FlushChanges and ClearChanges or SaveChanges should be kept minimal so that the server side transaction is short. There should not be a user interaction between the FlushChanges and the following ClearChanges or SaveChanges call.
For longer running import operations use

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.FlushChanges(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Flushes all current changes to the database but keeps the transaction running.
member.remarks:
All changes made so far in this context are sent to the server but the transaction is not committed. A following SaveChanges or ClearChanges is necessary to complete the operations. Flush can be used to see all changed information in the following queries or to get the server side calculated primary keys immediately. Use parameter 'true' during import operations. This helps freeing the memory for the flushed data.
FlushChanges will pin a database connection to the context, start a server side transaction and keeps that running until ClearChanges or SaveChanges is called. The time between FlushChanges and ClearChanges or SaveChanges should be kept minimal so that the server side transaction is short. There should not be a user interaction between the FlushChanges and the following ClearChanges or SaveChanges call.
The property returns a 'false' if the memory has been released.
The memory optimization might lead to level two cache anomalies. You can avoid them by manually evicting the level two cache after your final SaveChanges call.
member.param: Clean up the used memory of the participating objects.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.Translate``1(System.Data.Common.DbDataReader)
member.summary: Lazily materializes the current result of a DbDataReader into a specified type.

remarks.para: If a persistence capable type is specified, the result will be attached (merged) into the context.

The returned enumerable is evaluated lazily: No result element is created when the enumeration is not performed. This requires the calling code to either ensure that the reader is not closed or disposed until all the needed result elements are obtained. Usually, this can be forced with a .ToList() call.

member.param: Source data reader
member.returns: Materialized result

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.CreateObjectKeyWithVersion(System.Object)
member.summary: Creates an ObjectKey instance with version information, from a given persistent entity.
member.remarks: The parameter should be persistence capable and should be managed by this OpenAccessContext instance. The returned ObjectKey contains version information for the specified entity. The version information consists of key/value pairs for each field that is used to perform optimistic concurrency checks. If the type of the persistent entity uses the the returned ObjectKey does not contain any version information. No version information is returned for a new entity that is added to a context but not yet committed to the database via call to . Similarly no version information is returned for an entity that is removed from the context via .
member.param: Persistent entity whose ObjectKey is to be created
member.returns: ObjectKey instance representing the identity and version information of the parameter
member.exception: is a null reference
is not managed by this context

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.GetObjectByKey(Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKey)
member.summary: Returns an object identified by the specified object key.

remarks.para: This method attempts to find an instance with the specified identity and version, in the context.
The parameter can be obtained via a call to or or can be constructed by the user by explicitly specifying it's properties.

If the persistent object with the specified key is already loaded in the context, it's reference is returned. If there is no instance in the context with the same database identity as specified by the parameter, this method checks the second level cache,if it is enabled, to see if the object is present there and returns it. If the object is still not found this method executes a query in an attempt to load the object from the database and returns it.
This method raises an if no row with the specified identity is found.

If the contains version information this method will attempt to return an entity that is exactly the same version as specified in the key, else an is raised. The version information present in the key is compared against the version information read from the database. This comparison is not performed on the database server.
No change will be made to the state of the returned instance.

member.param: The key of the object to be found
member.returns: The persistent object found in the context or loaded from the database
member.exception: is a null reference.
Incompatible metadata specified in the .
When object with specified identity and version is not found.
When object with specified identity is found but the version does not match.

If the persistent object with the specified key is already loaded in the context, it's reference is returned. If the object is still not found this method executes a query in an attempt to load the object from the database and returns it.

If the contains version information this method will attempt to return an entity that is exactly the same version as specified in the key, else an is raised. The version information present in the key is compared against the version information read from the database. This comparison is not performed on the database server.
No change will be made to the state of the returned instance.

Use the TryGetObjectByKey method to avoid handling the or the raised by GetObjectByKey when the object cannot be found. This method will raise a if the metadata in the key is incompatible with the type of the requested entity.

member.param: The key of the object to be found
When this method returns contains the persistent object, found in the context or loaded from the database

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.TryGetObjectByKey``1(Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectKey,``0@)
member.summary: Returns an object identified by the specified object key.

remarks.para: This method attempts to find an instance with the specified identity and version, in the context.
The parameter can be obtained via a call to or or can be constructed by the user by explicitly specify it's properties.

If the persistent object with the specified key is already loaded in the context, it's reference is returned. If there is no instance in the context with the same database identity as specified by the parameter, this method checks the second level cache,if it is enabled, to see if the object is present there and returns it. If the object is still not found this method executes a query in an attempt to load the object from the database and returns it.

If the contains version information this method will attempt to return an entity that is exactly the same version as specified in the key, else an is raised. The version information present in the key is compared against the version information read from the database. This comparison is not performed on the database server.
No change will be made to the state of the returned instance.

Use the TryGetObjectByKey method to avoid handling the or the raised by GetObjectByKey when the object cannot be found. This method will raise a if the metadata in the key is incompatible with the type of the requested entity.

member.param: The key of the object to be found
When this method returns contains the persistent object, found in the context or loaded from the database
member.typeparam: The type of the expected object. If unknown use
member.returns: true if the object was retrieved successfully.false if the object with the specified identity and version is not found.
member.exception: is a null reference.
Incompatible metadata specified in the .

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.GetOriginalValue``1(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Returns the original value of the named property of field from the persistent object.

remarks.para: If a property or field in a persistent type is changed or marked as dirty, the original value might be of interest. This method can be used to access the original value if it is available.

Per default only the original values for types marked with concurrency mode are kept. If all original values are of interest, the context.ContextProperties.MaintainOriginalValues property has to be set to true.
To keep all original values in memory might have an memory overhead. If one field is made dirty, all fields of that respective type are stored in an extra object[].
If the object is new, the default value of the respective property type is returned. If the property or field is clean, the clean value is returned.

member.typeparam: The type of the expected return value. Object can be used for untyped access.
member.param: The object holding the field or property of interest.
The name of the property or field of interest.
member.returns: The old value if it was available and the property or field was dirty, the actual value otherwise.

If the no property or field with the specified name can be found.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.AttachCopy``1(``0)
member.summary: Attaches a copy of an object graph to the context.
member.remarks:
A copy of the given object graph rooting in the passed entity instance is made into the this context. When a new, deleted or changed instance exists in the context for an object in the graph, the operation fails.
Concurrency Control checks will be done during SaveChanges.
It is not supported to attach object graphs that mix entities coming from different contexts, as no graph boundary can reliably be made then. Only new (unmanaged) or detached instances can be passed.

member.param: The detached, persistence capable instance.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.DisposeDatabase
member.summary: Disposes the underlying database structure.
member.remarks:
The database instance is shared by all context instances that use the same connection string in their constructors. This call cleans up as much as possible, all contexts are not longer usable.
DisposeDatabase is meant to cleanup all resources when the connection to a certain database is not longer needed. The call also ensures that all logging information is written to the log file. In a web application, this call should be placed in the 'Application_End' call of 'Global.asax'.

member.summary: Specifies the destination to write the SQL query or command.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.ContextOptions
member.summary: Gets the Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextOptions instance that contains options that affect the behavior of the Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.
member.returns: The instance that contains options that affect the behavior of the .

members.member:
Controls whether the context behaves in data synchronization mode during Insert and Update operations. If the OpenAccessContextBase is in this mode, OpenAccess will skip calculation of the DateTime and version field values.
This property should be set to 'True' only if the context instance is used to synchronize the data between two databases. In such a scenario it is desired that the auto calculated fields such as the 'version' field are not recalculated since an exact copy of the data should be inserted in the target database.
Do not set this property to 'True' for a context that is used for normal operations. If set, it could lead to undesired database exceptions due to the default value of the field being inserted or updated.
/// A value that is true when data synchronization mode is enabled; otherwise false.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.Telerik#OpenAccess#IOpenAccessContextOptions#MaintainOriginalValues
member.summary: Controls whether the original values are loaded and kept when a field is changed.
member.remarks: MaintainOriginalValues has to set to true if the original values have to be available always. The memory consumption might increase per persistent object.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.Telerik#OpenAccess#IOpenAccessContextOptions#RefreshObjectsAfterSaveChanges
member.summary: Controls whether all loaded objects are refreshed in a new transaction.
member.remarks:
If SaveChanges() or ClearChanges() is called, the data in the loaded objects managed by the context might no longer reflect the database content. Other processes or clients might have modified data in the database as well. To make the optimistic concurrency control working better, Telerik Data Access reloads all data in a subsequent transaction.
The default is true, and this setting should only be changed with great care, as setting it to false might result in long-living stale objects.
Note, that the default value of true does not guarantee non-stale objects when using optimistic transactions. It does only guarantee, that objects used in previous transactions are refreshed on the first read access in subsequent transactions of the same context.
member.value: True if all objects should be refreshed in subsequent transactions, false otherwise. True is the default.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.Telerik#OpenAccess#IOpenAccessContextOptions#IsolationLevel
member.summary: Controls the isolation level of this contexts resources.
member.remarks:
When an isolation level is specified, the context will need to use transactions for read access.
When null is specified, the default isolation level (ReadCommitted) is used and transactions around read requests might be omitted (depending on the setting).
Not all database systems support all possible isolation levels, therefore only Snapshot, ReadCommitted and ReadUncommitted are currently supported.
The second level cache will not be used or populated when any value except null is specified for this context.
member.value: Isolation Level (Default: null)
member.exception: Wrong isolation level, only Snapshot, ReadCommitted and ReadUncommitted allowed.
Isolation level cannot be changed because a connection is active.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets an application specific name that can be used for correlation.
member.remarks: Giving the context a name in an application specific manner allows for easy correlation of the events obtainable from the class.
member.value: Application specific string or null

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.ReadOnly
member.summary: Controls if the context prevents changes to any data it is managing.
member.remarks:
In a read only context, all functionality that potentially changes data is prohibited.
The read only setting can be changed during the complete lifetime of the context. It can be set to false at any time, but to set it to true, the context must be clean, not enlisted in a distributed transaction and no context bound connection should be used directly.
member.value: Controls if the context prevents changes to any data it is managing.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.Connection
member.summary: Gets the connection used by the Telerik Data Access context.
member.remarks:
Use this property to obtain the connection that is used by the context to save its changes. The returned connection has a transaction started on it. All commands executed on this connection are automatically executed within this transaction. In order to commit or rollback the statements executed via the commands, you need to call the or method. Doing so will commit/rollback the actions performed by the statements as well as the changes in the context itself. The connection will be reserved for you until it is disposed - only then it will be returned to the connection pool. In order to avoid connection pool depletion, please make sure to dispose or wrap in using block the returned connection.
The returned connection and the transaction started on it are managed by the context i.e. committing and rolling back the transaction, opening and closing of the store connection are performed by the context. In case the context is disposed before the connection, it is the user's responsibility to call in order to ensure that the underlying store connection is closed.
Obtaining the connection affects the pooling behavior of the connection.
member.value: Connection that can be used to perform ADO operations

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.CacheKey
member.summary: Override this property in your context to use custom logic to calculate the key used to cache the model metadata. This property allows you to have a single context type that can be used with different models in the same AppDomain, or multiple context types that use the same model.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.Cache
member.summary: Returns the level one cache directly bound to this context.
member.remarks:
The context caches all new, dirty and deleted objects since the last SaveChanges or ClearChanges call.
All clean data is only held by a special structure to ensure the uniqueness of all entities in one context. The type of references from this structure can be controlled by the .
member.value: The level one cache directly bound to this context.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase.LevelTwoCache
member.summary: Returns the level two cache bound to all contexts using the same connection string.
member.remarks: The level two cache is a common cache used by all context instances that are created with the same connecting string. The level two cache is a read through cache that caches all read data based on the configuration.
member.value: The level two cache bound to all contexts using the same connection string.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.DefaultFetchGroupAttribute
member.summary: Specifies, whether this field is member of the so-called default fetch group. The default fetch group is the set of fields that are retrieved, if any field of the object is accessed the very first time.

remarks.para: Using this attribute is only needed for performance fine-tuning and if the default behavior is not sufficient.

For example fields of type System.Collection.ArrayList are by default not part of the default fetch group, because retrieving the values might need an additional database access. So an ArrayList member is not fetched until it is actually accessed. However this happens absolut transparently regardless whether it is in the default fetch group or not.

By default, fields of the following types are in the default fetch group:
all types derived from System.ValueType, e.g. System.Int32
System.String
By default, fields of the following types are not in the default fetch group:
all supported built-in types that implement System.Collections.ICollection
references to persistent objects or persistent interfaces
Requires, that the referenced class and the referencing class are marked as [Persistent].

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.DefaultFetchGroupAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: The field being tagged is member of the default fetch group.
member.remarks: Using this attribute is only needed for performance fine-tuning and if the default behavior is not sufficient.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.DefaultFetchGroupAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Controls whether the tagged field is a member of the default fetch group.
member.remarks: Using this attribute is only needed for performance fine-tuning and if the default behavior is not sufficient.
member.param: If true the member is included in the default fetch group, otherwise not.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.DefaultFetchGroupAttribute.IsIncluded
member.summary: Indicates whether the tagged member is included in the default fetch group.
member.value: true if the member is included
member.remarks: This property can be used to determine if the member is in the default fetch group.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute
member.summary: Declares a class to be persistence-capable. This attribute is not inherited and must be specified for each class in a class hierarchy individually. Only field values (no code) of persistent classes within a class hierarchy are stored in the database.

remarks.para: This attribute marks an application class as to be registered in the database schema. The attributed class becomes persistence-capable (implementing an additional interface) and is able to store/retrieve instances. Instances of a persistence-capable class can then be be stored in a database as persistent objects.

Per default, all fields of an instance of a persistence-capable class will be stored in the database. If this needs to be avoided, the can be used to mark a field as transient (not to be stored in the database).
This attribute is not inherited and must be used on every class in a class hierarchy.
This attribute will be used and processed by the Telerik.OpenAccess .NET enhancer and attributed classes will be persistence-capable only if the enhancer was run after compilation of the class.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Declares a class to be persistence-capable; instances of such a class can be made persistent in a database.
member.remarks: The [Persistent] attribute will be used by the Telerik.OpenAccess .NET enhancer to capture the database schema and to add persistence enabling methods and fields.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.GetAliasSet
member.summary: Indicates whether the Alias property was set.
member.value: true if the Alias property was given a value.
member.remarks: This property can be used to determine if the application specified the existence of an alias.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.Identity
member.summary: Determines, whether the identity for objects is automatically provided by the runtime system (internal identity) or is provided by the values of certain fields of an object.

remarks.para: From an object-oriented perspective, the identity of an object should not rely on its values. This means that, internal identity should be preferred. Single or multiple field identity on the other hand is particularly useful when working with legacy databases (i.e., the relational schema already exists.).

There are certain restrictions for the single field identity type. If certain fields should form the identity of a type, the single field identity type must consist of fields having the same name and type. Currently only fields of type System.Int16, System.Int32, System.Int64, System.Single, and System.String are supported for the id fields.

When multiple field identity is used within an inheritance hierarchy, all classes of that hierarchy must share the same multiple field identity type. Furthermore the fields to be used must be declared in the least-derived class of that hierarchy.

member.value: If set to a particular System.Type and not null then single field identity is used, otherwise internal identity is used. Defaults to null, meaning internal identity.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.ApplicationIdentity
member.summary: ApplicationIdentity is obsolete, please use Identity instead.
member.value: The identifying type for this persistent class.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.IdentityField
member.summary: Determines the field used for single field identity.

remarks.para: From an object-oriented perspective, the identity of an object should not rely on its values. This means internal identity should be preferred. Single or multiple field identity on the other hand is particularly useful when working with legacy databases (i.e., the relational schema already exists.).
When setting this property to the name of a field of the class marked with the [Persistent] attribute, the named field is treated as the holder of the primary key.

There are certain restrictions on the type of the named field. Currently only fields of type System.SByte, System.Int16, System.Int32, System.Int64, System.Guid, System.Char and System.String are supported for single field identity fields.

When single field identity is used within an inheritance hierarchy, all classes of that hierarchy must share the same single field identity type. Furthermore the fields to be used must be declared in the least-derived class of that hierarchy.
It is a logical error to specify both and / .

member.value: The name of a field to hold the identity (primary key). Defaults to null, meaning internal identity should be used.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.VersionField
member.summary: Determines the field used for optimistic concurrency control.

remarks.para: When setting this property to the name of a field of the class marked with the [Persistent] attribute, the named field is treated as the holder the version information.
There are certain restrictions on the type of the named field. Currently only fields of type System.SByte, System.Int16, System.Int32 and System.DateTime are supported for versioning fields.

When version field is set within an inheritance hierarchy, all classes of that hierarchy share the same version field setting. Furthermore the fields to be used must be declared in the least-derived class of that hierarchy.

member.value: The name of a field to hold the version information. Defaults to null.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.IdentityClassName
member.summary: Determines, whether the identity for objects is automatically provided by the runtime system (internal identity) or is provided by the values of certain fields of an object. Only intended for situations, where no type, but a string can be specified. (e.g. J#)
member.value: If set to the name of a particular System.Type and not null then single field identity is used, otherwise internal identity is used.
member.remarks: See .

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.ApplicationIdentityClassName
member.summary: ApplicationIdentityClassName is obsolete, please use IdentityClassName instead.
member.value: The name of the identifying type for this persistent class.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.PersistentAttribute.Alias
member.summary: Controls the alias name for the attributed class. Useful for OQL-Queries to abbreviate long class names.
member.remarks: The specified name will be available from the database schema. If no alias name was given, Telerik.OpenAccess .NET uses the name of the attributed class as alias name.
member.value: If an alias name was specified, its value will be returned here. Default is null.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransientAttribute
member.summary: Declares a field of a persistence-capable class to be transient, and its value will not be stored or maintained by the database.
member.remarks: This attribute can only be used on a field of a class marked with the [Persistent] attribute. The field will then not be treated as part of the schema of the persistence-capable class and the values it contains are not stored in the database.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransientAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Declares a field of a persistence-capable class to be transient.
member.remarks: Transient fields of a persistence-capable class will not be written to the database / loaded from the database.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.SerializeToBlobAttribute
member.summary: Declares a field of a persistence-capable class to be serialized and stored as a binary large object (Blob) in the database.
member.remarks:
Serialized values are not interpreted by the database. Therefore queries cannot be executed on them and indexes cannot be defined for them.
A BinaryFormatter is used to read and write objects from / to blobs.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.SerializeToBlobAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Declares a field member to be serialized and stored as a uninterpreted Blob.
member.remarks: Database operations like queries will not be possible on serialized members.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.DependAttribute
member.summary: Declares a referenced object to be dependent on the referencing object.
member.remarks:
This can be used to mark a referenced object as subordinate of another (this) object.
Requires, that the referenced class and the referencing class are marked as [Persistent].

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.DependAttribute.#ctor
member.summary: Declares a field member object as contingent upon the referencing object.
member.remarks: Using this attribute might be useful during removal of objects as dependend objects might need to be removed too.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.ItemTypeAttribute
member.summary: Specifies the item type for a Collection field or the key / value types for a IDictionary field of a persistence-capable class.

remarks.para: Requires, that the enclosing class is marked as [Persistent].

Is also used when designing Forms in Visual Studio .NET to determine the item type of collection-valued properties with the following algorithm:
if applied directly to the property this attribute determines the item type of the property directly
else if the class has a field that bears exactly the same name as the property except that the first character is lower-case and this field has the ItemType attribute applied, then this determines the item type of the property
else if the class has a field that bears an equal name (compared case-insensitive) as the property except that an underscore is prepended, then this determines the item type of the property
else is assumed as item type for the property
If applied to a field, then System.Object is not a supported item type for relational database backends.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute
member.summary: Marks a field as part of a named FetchGroup. A FetchGroup is a set of fields which are retrieved together when the FetchGroup name is contained in the actual FetchPlan configuration.

remarks.para: This attribute is used if the default behavior is not sufficient, and is needed for performance fine-tuning.
This attribute requires the containing class to be marked as [Persistent].
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Declares a field as part of a named FetchGroup.
member.param: The name of the FetchGroup.

remarks.para: Adds this field to the FetchGroup with the specified name. The fetch group is a collection of fields and can be defined on field level and can be combined with other FetchGroups on class level.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute.Next
member.summary: Sets a FetchGroup at the referenced class as the FetchGroup to be used.

remarks.para: If it is necessary to fetch a referenced object with a specific FetchGroup definition you can specify it here. The next FetchGroup is added only to the FetchPlan definition if the object is retrieved via this reference. The FetchGroup name must be part of the actual FetchPlan.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.value: Name of the FetchGroup to be used next.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute.KeyNext
member.summary: Sets a FetchGroup for the key field at the referenced class as the FetchGroup to be used.

remarks.para: If it is necessary to fetch a referenced object with a specific FetchGroup definition you can specify it here. The next FetchGroup is added only to the FetchPlan definition if the object is retrieved via this reference. The FetchGroup name must be part of the actual FetchPlan.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.value: Name of the FetchGroup to be used next for the key reference.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute.Path
member.summary: Adds a specific field at the referenced class to the FetchGroup.
member.remarks:
If you need a spefic field at the referenced object it is not necessary to define a FetchGroup at the referenced class. You can use the path argument to do this indirectly.
You also can traverse over more then one level to use the '.' as seperator.
If the field is a collection the path has to specify this. The syntax is: #element.childname
If the field is a dictionary the path has to mention if the key or value reference should be used. The syntax is: #key.fieldname or #value.fieldname. If you do not want to retrieve key and value the path has to be #key or #value.
member.value: Path specification

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute.KeyPath
member.summary: Adds a specific field for the key at the referenced class to the FetchGroup.

remarks.para: If you need a spefic field at the referenced object it is not necessary to define a FetchGroup at the referenced class. You can use the path argument to do this indirectly.
You also can traverse over more then one level to use the '.' as seperator.
If the field is a collection the path has to specify this. The syntax is: #element.childname

member.value: Path specification

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute.Depth
member.summary: Controls the depth of the fetch operation.

remarks.para: The Depth parameter defines the maximum depth the referenced objects are fetched from this point.
The default value for Depth is always 1! This means that only the referenced object is loaded. If you want to load additional data you have to increase the depth.

This parameter is important if you define circular references. If you have a Person class with Children collection field (elements are also Person objects), an unlimited Depth will fetch all Persons if you start with Adam.
The depth of the fetching operation is also limited by the FetchPlan.MaxDepth property. It might be necessary to increase this value too to achieve the desired fetch effect.

member.value: The maximum number of levels to be fetched. (Default: 1)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute.KeyDepth
member.summary: Controls the depth of the fetch operation on the key part.

remarks.para: The Depth parameter defines the maximum depth the referenced objects are fetched from this point.
The default value for Depth is always 1! This means that only the referenced object is loaded. If you want to load additional data you have to increase the depth.

This parameter is important if you define circular references. If you have a Person class with Children collection field (elements are also Person objects), an unlimited Depth will fetch all Persons if you start with Adam.
The depth of the fetching operation is also limited by the FetchPlan.MaxDepth property. It might be necessary to increase this value too to achieve the desired fetch effect.

member.value: The maximum number of levels to be fetched. (Default: 1)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchFieldAttribute.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the FetchGroup.
member.remarks:
The name is the name as specified by the constructor and must match the name of the .
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.
member.value: FetchGroup name.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchGroupAttribute
member.summary: Declares a named FetchGroup on class level. The FetchGroup is a set of fields which are retrieved together if the fetch group name is part of the actual FetchPlan configuration.

remarks.para: This attribute is used if the default behavior is not sufficient, and is needed for performance fine-tuning.
You can combine various fetch group definitions with this attribute. The fields, which are part of the named fetch group are defined directly at the field level.
Requires, that the class is marked as [Persistent].
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.remarks:

It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

FetchGroups can include other FetchGroups.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchGroupAttribute.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the FetchGroup. All FetchGroups with the same name are used at the same time.
member.remarks:
A descriptive name, for example a use case name, makes it easier to see the FetchGroups meaning.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.
member.value: The name of the FetchGroup.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchGroupAttribute.Groups
member.summary: Gets the collection of referenced FetchGroups.
member.remarks: You can combine various FetchGroups to a new one by specifing their names.
member.value: The names of the FetchGroups.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.FieldAliasAttribute
member.summary: Declares the property to be an alias for a field during OQL query evaluation.
member.remarks:
This attribute marks the property as an alias for a field, so that the properties name can be used in an OQL query expression. This is useful to abstract from the given field name and allows to use the names of public properties in OQL expressions instead of the field names.
Please note, that the property is not evaluated during OQL expression evaluation, but the name of the property is replaced with the field name given in the FieldAlias attribute constructor.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FieldAliasAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Declares a property to be an alias for the given field.
member.remarks: Currently, the usage of the correct field is not checked by the enhancer.
member.param: A valid field name.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FieldAliasAttribute.FieldName
member.summary: Gets the name of the field to query for this property.
member.value: A valid field name.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.ManagedInverseAttribute
member.summary: Declares a collection to be managed by it's reverse relationship field.
member.remarks:
In essence, this attribute declares that the attributed collection is calculated through the inverse field and that the inverse's field content should be managed automatically when modifications happen on the attributed side.
There are kinds of collection management currently possible:
1:n with join table - No attribute necessary.
1:n with invers held collection - The inverse is a single visible reference.
1:n with invers automatic collection - The inverse is a hidden automatic reference.
m:n collections - The inverse is a collection of references.
Declaring a collection field to be managed by it's inverse relationship can avoid coding errors.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ManagedInverseAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Declares a inverse field of a managed relationship.
member.remarks: Currently, the correct existence of the field is not checked by the enhancer.
member.param: A valid field name of the inverse type or {auto} for automatic held reference.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ManagedInverseAttribute.InverseFieldName
member.summary: Gets the name of the inverse field.
member.value: A valid field name for the type of the inverse side.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Blob
member.summary: Implements binary large objects (Blob) which are accessed as a whole.
member.remarks:
This class allows to store large amounts of bytes. Data is completely loaded when the enclosing persistent object is loaded.
Instances of this class are always second class objects.
Blobs can be accessed only within an active transaction.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Database
member.summary: Represents one database which is identified by an URL; serves as factory object for transactions, queries, object identities.

remarks.para: A is identified by a Connection Id. The passed connection id is defined in the Configuration File.
The database object can be used to obtain connections () for this database.
A physical connection is opened when the first is requested. The connection is closed, when the last is disposed.

example.para:
The following method shows how easy it is to
create a persistent instance,
retrieve it back by using it's
object identity (our representation of the primary key values),
update it by just assigning a new value and committing the transaction
remove that instance from the database.
In the Main method a database is opened and a workspace in which persistent instances live is generated.
There must be a connection with identifier DatabaseConnection1 be defined in the application configuration file.

para.note: All modifying methods must be executed in the context of an active transaction; otherwise an exception will occur.

example.code:
Friend Class Program ' Please see the comments in the C# example, which is equivalent Public Sub New() End Sub
Private Shared Sub CRUD(ByVal scope As IObjectScope) Dim p As New Person p.Name = "Kevin" scope.Transaction.Begin scope.Add(p) scope.Transaction.Commit Dim oid As IObjectId = scope.GetObjectId(p) Using scope2 As IObjectScope = scope.Database.GetObjectScope Dim p2 As Person = DirectCast(scope2.GetObjectById(oid), Person) Console.WriteLine(p.Name) End Using scope.Transaction.Begin p.Name = "Thomas" scope.Transaction.Commit scope.Transaction.Begin scope.Remove(p) scope.Transaction.Commit End Sub
Private Shared Sub Main(ByVal args As String()) Using scope As IObjectScope = Database.Get("DatabaseConnection1").GetObjectScope Program.CRUD(scope) End Using End Sub
End Class

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Database.Get(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the database object for the passed connection id using the application configuration file.
member.remarks:
If this method is called more than once with the same id, the same Database instance is returned.
The database is not opened yet; it will be opened when the first object is requested.
member.param: The connection id for the database.
member.returns: The Database instance.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Database.Get(System.String,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Returns the database object for the passed connection id and configuration information.
member.remarks:
If this method is called more than once with the same id, the same Database instance is returned.
An XmlElement can be specified that contains the config information to be used instead of the information contained in the executables application configuration file.
The database is not opened yet; it will be opened when the first object is requested.
It is not supported to use the same connectionId with different config override nodes, or one time with and one time without config override. The behavior is not specified for this case.
Attention: None of the provided tools can read the passed config override, so use with care!
Example usage:
const string myconfig = "<openaccess>"+ "<references>"+ "<reference assemblyname='ClassLibrary1' />"+ "</references>"+ "<connections>"+ "<connection id='DatabaseConnection1'>"+ "<databasename>myDatabase</databasename>"+ "<servername>localhost</servername>"+ "<user>myuser</user>"+ "<password>mypassword</password>"+ "<backendconfigurationname>mssqlConfiguration</backendconfigurationname>"+ "</connection>"+ "</connections>"+ "<backendconfigurations>"+ "<backendconfiguration id='mssqlConfiguration' backend='mssql'>"+ "<mappingname>mssqlMapping</mappingname>"+ "<!-- logging.logEvents>all</logging.logEvents>"+ "<logging.logEventsToSysOut>true</logging.logEventsToSysOut-->"+ "</backendconfiguration>"+ "</backendconfigurations>"+ "<mappings current='mssqlMapping'>"+ "<mapping id='mssqlMapping' />"+ "</mappings>"+ "</openaccess>"; XmlDocument xmlDoc = new XmlDocument(); xmlDoc.LoadXml(myconfig); Database db = Database.Get("DatabaseConnection1", xmlDoc.DocumentElement);
The passed XmlElement is used instead of the database configuration node in the application configuration file. However this does not necessarily replace the mapping nodes of other referenced assemblies: The mapping configuration of those is still used when referenced (via the reference subelement) from the passed node.
member.param: The connection id for the database.
The XmlElement representing the database configuration node and all subnodes of the configuration.
member.returns: The Database instance.
member.exception: No connectionId given.
No configOverride given.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Database.Get(System.String,System.Xml.XmlElement,System.Reflection.Assembly[])
member.summary: Returns the database object for the passed connection id, configuration information and the list of assemblies with persistent class information.
member.remarks:
If this method is called more than once with the same id, the same Database instance is returned.
An XmlElement can be specified that contains the config information to be used instead of the information contained in the executables application configuration file.
A list of assemblies has to be specified that contains the definition of all persistent classes. Normally the process entry assembly is used to find the classes. With this method it is possible to specify also assemblies that are not referenced by the entry assembly. All assemblies must be loaded.
The database is not opened yet; it will be opened when the first object is requested.
It is not supported to use the same connectionId with different config override nodes, or one time with and one time without config override. The behavior is not specified for this case.
Attention: None of the provided tools can read the passed config override, so use with care!
Example usage:
const string myconfig = "<openaccess>"+ "<references>"+ "<reference assemblyname='ClassLibrary1' />"+ "</references>"+ "<connections>"+ "<connection id='DatabaseConnection1'>"+ "<databasename>myDatabase</databasename>"+ "<servername>localhost</servername>"+ "<user>myuser</user>"+ "<password>mypassword</password>"+ "<backendconfigurationname>mssqlConfiguration</backendconfigurationname>"+ "</connection>"+ "</connections>"+ "<backendconfigurations>"+ "<backendconfiguration id='mssqlConfiguration' backend='mssql'>"+ "<mappingname>mssqlMapping</mappingname>"+ "<!-- logging.logEvents>all</logging.logEvents>"+ "<logging.logEventsToSysOut>true</logging.logEventsToSysOut-->"+ "</backendconfiguration>"+ "</backendconfigurations>"+ "<mappings current='mssqlMapping'>"+ "<mapping id='mssqlMapping' />"+ "</mappings>"+ "</openaccess>"; XmlDocument xmlDoc = new XmlDocument(); xmlDoc.LoadXml(myconfig); Database db = Database.Get("DatabaseConnection1", xmlDoc.DocumentElement);
The passed XmlElement is used instead of the database configuration node in the application configuration file. However this does not necessarily replace the mapping nodes of other referenced assemblies: The mapping configuration of those is still used when referenced (via the reference subelement) from the passed node.
member.param: The connection id for the database.
The XmlElement representing the database configuration node and all subnodes of the configuration.

The list of all assemblies with persistent classes inside. Use this method only if your application is not linked directly or indirectly to the persistent classes assemblies. Only this list of assemblies will be used, it must be complete!
member.returns: The Database instance.
member.exception: No connectionId given
No configOverride given
No entryAssemblies given

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Database.Get(System.String,Telerik.OpenAccess.BackendConfiguration,Telerik.OpenAccess.Metadata.MetadataContainer)
member.summary: Returns the database object for the given connection string, backend configuration and mapping settings.
member.remarks:
This method can be used to programatically control all aspects of database configuration.
The parameter can be used in two principal ways:
With a plain connection string value (e.g. 'Data Source=.\\SQLEXPRESS;Initial Catalog=Northwind;Integrated Security=True')
With a connection string name (e.g. 'DatabaseConnection1')
The first form (plain connection string) requires the setting of the property in the as OpenAccess cannot deduce the intended driver.
The second form is more flexible (and recommended) because the name will be resolved with the application configuration settings. The backend value omittable when a ProviderName is present in the connection string settings.
member.param: Connection String OR Connection String Name
Backend configuration
Metadata container obtained via one of the Metadata collectors
member.returns: The unopened, but configured database instance.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IDatabaseProperties.ConnectionTimeout
member.summary: Controls the timeout of database client/server connections after the last ObjectScope disposal.

remarks.para: Database client/server connections are closed ConnectionTimeout milliseconds after the last object scope associated with the connection is disposed. If a new object scope is obtained in the meantime, the connection is not closed.
By default, the timeout is -1, i.e. connections are never closed.

This property can only be set, if the database has no open connections. It is mostly useful in application server scenarios, where closing the last ObjectScope might not immediately mean, that the database server connections are to be closed too.

member.value: The timeout value is given in milliseconds.
member.exception: Database has already been opened.

member.remarks: For more information about this setting see enumeration.
member.exception: The database has already been opened.
member.value: Indicates which transaction provider is (to be) used.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ISchemaHandler.CreateUpdateDDLScript(Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties)
member.summary: Calculates the DDL script for updating the database to the current version of the enhanced classes and mapping information.
member.remarks:
Updating the database will alter the database schema so that the tables and procedures match the definitions as given by the enhanced classes and their mapping.
The generated string can be used with to migrate the database schema.
CreateUpdateDDLScript will block other threads in the methods and will fail when the database has active object scopes.
member.param: Values controlling the update calculation process or null if the defaults are to be used.
member.returns: String with the needed updates.

The generated string can be used with to migrate the database schema.
CreateDDLScript will block other threads in the methods and will fail when the database has active object scopes.
