member.value: Script contains statements generting primary key constraints on existing tables.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateInfo.AddsPKConstraintOnNewTable
member.summary: Adds a primary key constraint to an new table, the create table statement is included as well.
member.value: Script contains statements generting primary key constraints on new tables.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateInfo.RemovesPKConstraintFromExistingTable
member.summary: Removes a primary key constraint from an existing table.
member.remarks: This is a structural change to the existing schema that can lead to broken queries on other clients.
member.value: Script contains statements removing primary key constraints from existing tables.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateInfo.AddsOther
member.summary: Script contains artifacts that adds structures independent of existing.
member.remarks: The script might add stored procedures, triggers or sequences.
member.value: Script contains statements generting new artifacts.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateInfo.ModifiesOther
member.summary: Script contains artifacts that modifies existing structures.
member.remarks: The script might modify stored procedures, triggers or sequences.
member.value: Script contains statements modifying artifacts.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateInfo.IsTrivial
member.summary: Script contains schema artifacts without influencing the existing schema.
member.remarks: The script can contain statements that adds new tables, their constraints or indexes. Existing structures are not modified or extended.
member.value: Script contains only trivial statements.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateInfo.IsExtending
member.summary: Script contains schema artifacts that extend the existing schema.
member.remarks: The script can contain statements that add columns, constraints or indexes to existing tables. Independent artifacts like new tables, their constraints or indexes are allowed as well.
member.value: Script contains only statements adding artifacts to existing structures or new structures.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateInfo.IsComplex
member.summary: Script contains schema artifacts with structural changes.
member.remarks: The script contains statements that changes the structure of existing schema artifactes like tables, constraints or indexes. This script should not be executed when other clients are using the database because assumptions they made when the clients were created can be broken. Esp. queries on tables that are structurally changed, columns are removed or changed in type, will not work any longer.
member.value: Script contains complex statements, changing existing structures.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties
member.summary: Control switches for the database schema migration
member.remarks: An instance of this type can be used to control the behavior of the schema update algorithm.
member.example: Please see for an example.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckConstraint
member.summary: Controls if constraints are migrated
member.remarks: Per default, constraints are migrated
member.value: True if constraints are migrated. (Default: True)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckExtraColumns
member.summary: Controls if additional (non-schema described) columns are migrated
member.remarks: Per default, additional columns of a table will be removed. To suppress this behavior, set this property to False.
member.value: True if additional columns are migrated. (Default: True)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckExtraIndexes
member.summary: Controls if additional (non-schema described) indexes are migrated
member.remarks: Per default, additional indexes of a table will be removed. To suppress this behavior, set this property to False.
member.value: True if additional indexes are migrated. (Default: True)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckIndex
member.summary: Controls if indexes are migrated
member.remarks: Per default, indexes are migrated.
member.value: True if indexes are migrated. (Default: True)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckLength
member.summary: Controls if length checks are performed during migration
member.remarks: Per default, column length settings are migrated.
member.value: True if column length differences are checked in migration. (Default: True)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckNulls
member.summary: Controls if nullability checks are performed during migration
member.remarks: Per default, nullability settings are migrated.
member.value: True if column nullability differences are checked in migration. (Default: True)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckPK
member.summary: Controls if primary key checks are performed during migration
member.remarks: Per default, primary keys are checked during migration.
member.value: True if primary key checks are made during migration. (Default: True)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckScale
member.summary: Controls if column scale checks are performed during migration
member.remarks: Per default, column scale difference checks are made during migrations.
member.value: True if column scale differences are checked during migration. (Default: True)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.SchemaUpdateProperties.CheckType
member.summary: Controls if column type checks are performed during migration
member.remarks:
Per default, column type difference checks are made during migration.
When set to False, the types of the columns are not compared.
member.value: True if column types are checked during migration.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent
member.summary: Interface for events generated by log tracing.
member.remarks: Instances of this class are used with the System.Diagnostics.Trace framework. The method is used for tracing; the first argument is an instance of ITraceEvent, the category is set to the product name.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the event.
member.remarks: Event names are in the form of module.action or level.module.action.
member.value: Event name

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.Description
member.summary: Gets the description of the event.
member.remarks: Event descriptions contain the logical parameters of the performed action.
member.value: Event description

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.EventType
member.summary: Gets the internal numerical representation of the event type.
member.remarks: The returned internal value can be used to distinguish between events.
member.value: Numerical value discriminating the type of the event

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.EventId
member.summary: Gets the event instance identification.
member.remarks: During the creation of the event, an unique number is assigned to it.
member.value: Numerical value for identification purposes

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.ConnectionId
member.summary: Gets the identification of the physical connection.
member.remarks: There is no general correspondence between physical connections and an user visible context.
member.value: Connection discriminator value

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.StatementId
member.summary: Gets the database statement identification.
member.remarks: The value returned identifies a driver statement.
member.value: Statement discriminator value

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.ResultId
member.summary: Gets the database result set identification.
member.remarks: The value returned identifies a driver result set.
member.value: Result set discriminator value

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.ContextId
member.summary: Gets the context identification.
member.remarks: The value returned identifies a pooled instance.
member.value: Context id

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.ErrorMessage
member.summary: Gets the error message.
member.remarks: In case an error was raised during the execution of a method, the error message can provide useful information. Note, that the error message format is driver and database specific.
member.value: Error message

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.FetchGroup
member.summary: Gets the name of the fetch group used.
member.remarks: The value returned can be used to trace the fetch group resolution.
member.value: Fetch Group name

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.FieldName
member.summary: Gets the name of the field causing lazy loading or modification.
member.remarks: The value returned can be used to obtain information about the access pattern of the database.
member.value: Field name

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.Query
member.summary: Gets the actual query string.
member.remarks: The value returned can be used to obtain insight in the executed queries.
member.value: Query expression

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.Timestamp
member.summary: Gets the start time (UTC).
member.remarks: Events are marked with a start time in UTC.
member.value: Start Time of the event in UTC.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.Duration
member.summary: Gets the duration.
member.remarks: Events are marked with a duration if they are client/server actions.
member.value: Duration of the event.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.Information
member.summary: Gets the information associated with this event (query, correlation, etc.)
member.remarks: Events usually have some properties associated with it like query string or correlation. The information most important to the event can be accessed by this property.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.ContextName
member.summary: Gets the name of the context that caused this event.
member.remarks: The name of the context is available with the property.
member.value: Application controlled value

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent.BatchedStatements
member.summary: Gets the number of batched statements in this event.
member.remarks: When statement batching is enabled by , this property returns the number of batched statements with the same SQL.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter
member.summary: Handler for all trace and debugging messages
member.remarks:
This class contains a singleton instance which is used by the runtime system to generate and control tracing and debugging messages.
See the example on how to use the configuration file to control the listeners (trace source) and amount of tracing generated (trace switch).
For more information on tracing see also .
The implementation of this class uses the WriteLine(x,"Telerik.OpenAccess") (.Net 1.1) and TraceEvent() and TraceData (.Net 2) methods.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.Instance
member.summary: The instance used by all trace and debugging output.
member.remarks: This singleton provides the object used to handle all tracing and debugging messages and to control the level of tracing.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.ResetLevel(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the level value to the specified one. Allows you to set value lower than the current one (for example switching from "verbose" to "none" level).
member.remarks:
Allowed friendly names include:
0 = none, off, false
1 = error, critical
2 = normal, warning
3 = information
4 = verbose
5 = all
member.param: The new value. Accept raw numeric values as well as their friendly names ("none", "error", "normal", "information", "verbose", "all" and etc.)

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.TraceError
member.summary: Indicates whether error trace messages will be generated.
member.remarks: 'Critical' messages are treated as equal to 'Error' messages, so they are synonymous.
member.returns: True when error trace messages are beeing generated, False otherwise.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.TraceError(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Writes an error trace message.
member.remarks: The message will only be generated when the corresponding level is configured.
member.param: The format string.
An array of parameters or null.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.TraceWarning
member.summary: Indicates whether error or warning trace messages will be generated.
member.remarks: When warning messages are enabled, error (critical) messages are enabled too.
member.returns: True when warning trace messages are beeing generated, False otherwise.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.TraceWarning(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Writes a warning trace message.
member.remarks: The message will only be generated when the corresponding level is configured.
member.param: The format string.
An array of parameters or null.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.TraceInformation
member.summary: Indicates whether error, warning or information trace messages will be generated.
member.remarks: When information messages are enabled, error (critical) and warning messages are enabled too.
member.returns: True when information trace messages are beeing generated, False otherwise.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.TraceInformation(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Writes an information trace message.
member.remarks: The message will only be generated when the corresponding level is configured.
member.param: The format string.
An array of parameters or null.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.TraceVerbose
member.summary: Indicates whether error, warning, information or verbose trace messages will be generated.
member.remarks: When verbose messages are enabled, error (critical), warning and information messages are enabled too.

member.summary: Writes a verbose or debug trace message.

An array of parameters or null.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.Trace(System.Int32,Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.ITraceEvent)
member.summary: Writes an internal trace event message.
member.remarks: This method is not intended for customer use.
member.param: The trace event to write. Must not be null.
The level (1=error,2=warning,3=info,4=verbose) of th event to write.

members.member:
Prints timing information
The timing information is printed directly to the debugger output window.
The format of the string returned about the timing The arguments passed to the formated string Whether timing information is printed is controlled by the Telerik.OpenAccess.Timing trace switch.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.Level
member.summary: Controls the amount of trace messages being generated. If the new level value is considered lower than the currently set no change will be performed. In order to set the level to a lower one please use method.
member.remarks:
The level classifies the setting upon the severity of the message. The level can be set by the configuration file with a switch named "Telerik.OpenAccess".
The level can also contain values greater than 4 (which stands for 'Verbose') in order to fine-control the level of verbosity.
member.value: String value representing either the numerical value or one of the values 'Off', 'Error' (here equal to 'Critical'), 'Warning', 'Information', 'Verbose'.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.Tracing
member.summary: Indicates whether any trace message will be generated.
member.remarks: This is identical to returning a value other than "0".
member.value: True when trace messages are beeing generated, False otherwise.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Diagnostics.TraceAdapter.Listeners
member.summary: Gets the collection of listeners that is monitoring the trace output.
member.remarks:
The listeners produce formatted output from the trace output. By default, the collection contains an instance of the class. If you want to remove the default listener, call the
method, and pass it the instance of the DefaultTraceListener.
member.value: A TraceListenerCollection that represents a collection of type TraceListener monitoring this trace output.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessException.InnerExceptions
member.summary: Gets the exception(s) causing this exception to be thrown.
member.remarks:
This property can be useful to determine the chain for errors leading to this exception.
A single inner exception will be retrievable from the property in future versions.
member.value: Array with causing exceptions, possibly of size 1 or null.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessException.FailedObject
member.summary: Gets the object ID of the object causing this exception.
member.remarks:
The returned object ID is the database object identity for the object which caused this exception.
The returned IObjectId instance can be used with the method to resolve the logical database ID to an object reference.
member.value: The representation of the object causing this exception or null if the object ID was not available.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessException.BackendError
member.summary: Gets the database backend-specific error.
member.remarks: The returned object can be used to obtain more backend-specific information, i.e. the backend error number and an error description.
member.value: Database-backend specific error object.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessException.Reason
member.summary: Gets the concrete error code for this exception.
member.remarks: The enumeration provides fine-grained error detail codes which can be used to determine the exact cause of an exception.
member.value: The exact cause for this exception.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessException.CanRetry
member.summary: Indicates whether this exception is caused by a temporal problem.
member.remarks:
This property is useful to decide, if the calling application can succeed when trying the same operation again.
For example: If a lock conflict exists (LockNotGrantedException is thrown), the application would succeed after the lock has been released by the other transaction/application.
member.value: True if the application can try again and might succeed.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessException.HelpLink
member.summary: Gets a link to the help file associated with this exception.
member.value: The Uniform Resource Name (URN) or Uniform Resource Locator (URL).
member.remarks: This property will help the application developer to find information about a given error quickly.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Exceptions.CommunicationException
member.summary: The exception that is thrown when a communication failure with the database occures.
member.remarks:
If the exception occured after successful opening of a database, it might be caused by several reasons:
The network connection to the database server was broken.
The database server was shut down.
The computer of the database server was shut down.
If the exception occured during opening of a database, it might be cause by using an invalid or no-longer-valid name of a server or by a configuration problem.
The property can be used to determine the exact cause of the problem.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Exceptions.DataStoreException
member.summary: The exception that is thrown when a database storage failure occurs.
member.remarks:
Exceptions of this type usually mean one of the following:
The database and the schema do not match (the schema might have evolved).
The database cannot be accessed/opened.
A administrative database operation was interrupted previously and needs to be redone.
The database is in an inconsistent state and requires attention.
The property can be used to determine the exact cause of the problem.

member.summary: The exception that is thrown when the database storage could not be found.
member.remarks:
This exception might be caused by several reasons:
The logical name of the database is wrong.
The name is case-sensitive.
The logical name of the database is mapped to a wrong physical name.
The logical name of the server is wrong.
Maybe the wrong database server is contacted.
The logical name of the server is mapped to a wrong name on the client side.
Consult the configuration file.
The client used a physical name which is not valid any more on the server.
Physical names should not be used as they limit flexibility and managability.
The database was deleted.
Backslashes '\\' are not be understood by all operating systems in the same way, or there are too many of them (logical names will not contain them).
The database you thought existed exists not.
All mapped names are case-sensitive, only physical path names might be insensitive on case-insensitive file systems.
This exception corresponds to the value.
This exception includes database request information in the Message property to be more useful when thrown.

member.remarks:
This exception might be thrown when using pessimistic concurrency control.
When another transaction has the object already locked with a lock mode conflicting with the current request, this exception is thrown.
This exception can be avoided when optimistic locking is used by the transactions; see .

The object identifier string causing the exception can be retrieved from the property.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Exceptions.OptimisticVerificationException
member.summary: The exception that is thrown when a persistent object was stored concurrently.
member.remarks:
This exception might be thrown when using optimistic concurrency control.
Optimistic verification is a process in which version stamps of persistent objects are compared. A conflict is detected, when a persistent object was modified by the application, but has already been altered in the database in the meantime by another application. Every modification will change the version stamp of the persistent object and can therefore be detected.
This exception can occur as top-exception and as leaf-exception. In the top-exception case it provides access to a set of conflicting objects. In the leaf-exception case it provides access to a single object conflict. This means, an instance of this type might hold other instances of this type, when more than one object conflic was detected during optimistic verification.
The optimistic application has read an object and tries to update the database with its modifications but the object in the database was changed in the meantime by another transaction. This would cause application inconsistencies and therefore this exception is thrown.
This exception can be avoided when pessimistic locking is used by the transactions; see .
This exception can be thrown by the ITransaction.Commit method.
This exception can also be thrown by the during the and
methods, when concurrently changed objects are detected. In this case, the
and
methods can be used to determine the exact cause(s) for this exception.
This exception corresponds to the value.
To analyse the failed object(s) this pattern makes sense:
catch (Telerik.OpenAccess.Exceptions.OptimisticVerificationException e) { for (int i = 0; i < e.NumberOfConflicts; i++) Console.WriteLine("Conflicting Object: " + e.Conflict(i).FailedObject); }

and
methods.

member.summary: Provides methods to calculate the object network of a root object.

remarks.para: This class implements the interface. It calculates the object network, starting from the 'root object' specified in the method. Fetch groups can be used to specify which object members will be loaded while resolving the object network.
This class can be used in conjunction with the to fill it with a customized network of persistent objects.

Implementations of this interface are provided in the form of the class.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchGroupCollector.DefaultFetchGroup
member.summary: Used to specify that the 'Default' fetch group is to be used in the Collect method.
member.remarks:
Use this value in a call to the method to specify that all the fields in the 'Default' fetch group will be loaded while loading an object in memory.
For more information on Fetch groups refer to the Programmer's Guide.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchGroupCollector.DeepFetchGroup
member.summary: Used to specify that the 'Deep' fetch group is to be used in the Collect method.
member.remarks:
Use this value in a call to the method to specify that the 'Deep' fetch group is to be used while loading an object in memory.
The 'Deep' fetch group specifies that while loading an object in memory, all objects referenced from this given object will also be resolved and loaded in memory. This algorithm is applied recursively.
For more information on Fetch groups refer to the Programmer's Guide.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchGroupCollector.DependFetchGroup
member.summary: Used to specify that the 'Depend' fetch group is to be used in the Collect method.
member.remarks:
Use this value in a call to the method to specify that the 'Depend' fetch group is to be used while loading an object in memory.
The 'Depend' fetch group specifies that while loading an object in memory, only members that have the specified will be loaded. This algorithm is applied recursively.
For more information on Fetch groups refer to the Programmer's Guide.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan
member.summary: Interface for setting and changing the actual FetchPlan.

remarks.para: The FetchPlan is an array of strings. Every string represents a collection of fields as defined by the named FetchGroups. The FetchGroups are defined on class and field level.
There are two special FetchGroup names:
FetchPlan.Default names the default mechanism that is defined over the field types and the [DefaultFetchGroup(true|false)] attribute.
FetchPlan.All names all fields of an object including referenced objects one level deep.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.
The currently active FetchPlan instance can be obtained from the IObjectScope.FetchPlan property.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.Default
member.summary: Default FetchGroup name definition.
member.remarks: The FetchPlan.Default string is always part of the FetchPlan unless you remove it explicitly or call .

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.All
member.summary: Maximum FetchGroup name definition.
member.remarks: The FetchPlan.All string has to be used very careful. All fields of an object are fetched together, including the referenced objects one level deep.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.DefaultMaxDepth
member.summary: Default value for maximum fetch depth.
member.remarks:
Defines the default maximum tree depth that is fetched together. This controls the initial value of the MaxDepth property.
Currently, the value 3 is used for this constant.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.NoLimit
member.summary: Unlimited retrieval of objects in one fetch operation.
member.remarks: Defines that there is no restriction on the number of objects that can be fetched together. This value can be used with the property.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.DefaultLimit
member.summary: Default value for retrieval of objects in one fetch operation.
member.remarks: Defines the amount of objects that can be fetched together. This is also the initial value of the property. The default is internally set to 50 or to the value if this is set.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance.
member.remarks: This constructor is for internal use.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.#ctor(System.String[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new instance.

example.para: This example shows how to define a new FetchPlan and use it for future queries on the scope. The new FetchPlan definition contains 3 fetchgroups and a MaxDepth of 4 with no limit on the number of objects fetched.
The user can further modify the FetchPlan definition by calling methods like Add,Remove etc on the FetchPlan object.

member.param: The FetchGroup array consists of FetchGroup name that has to be defined as [FetchField(groupName)] at the field of a class that you want to fetch. FetchPlan.Default or FetchPlan.All is also possible.
Controls the maximum tree depth for an object to be fetched. This assigns the value of the MaxDepth property.
Value for retrieval of objects in one fetch operation. This assigns the value of the Limit property.
member.remarks: FetchGroups can include other FetchGroups.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.Add(System.String)
member.summary: Adds a FetchGroup name to the actual FetchPlan definition.
member.param: The FetchGroup name has to be defined as [FetchField(groupName)] at the field of a class that you want to fetch. FetchPlan.Default or FetchPlan.All is also possible.
member.returns: Returns the changed FetchPlan. You can call: scope.FetchPlan.Add("grp1").Add("grp2")... several times.
member.remarks:
The FetchPlan is used until the end of the operation. On scope level until you Dispose the IObjectScope object.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.Remove(System.String)
member.summary: Removes a FetchGroup name from the actual FetchPlan definition.
member.param: The FetchGroup name has to be defined as [FetchField(groupName)] at the field of a class that you want to fetch. FetchPlan.Default or FetchPlan.All is also possible.
member.returns: Returns the changed FetchPlan. You can call: scope.FetchPlan.Remove("grp1").Remove("grp2")... several times.
member.remarks:
The FetchPlan is used until the end of the operation. On scope level until you Dispose the IObjectScope object.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.Clear
member.summary: Clears the actual FetchPlan definition.
member.returns: Returns the changed FetchPlan. You can call: scope.FetchPlan.Clear().Add("grp1").Add("grp2")... several times.
member.remarks: The FetchPlan is cleared completly and the FetchPlan.Default FetchGroup is also removed! If you need this you have to add it again. The FetchPlan is used until the end of the operation. On scope level until you Dispose the IObjectScope object.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.Set(System.String)
member.summary: Replaces the actual FetchPlan by a single FetchGroup name.
member.param: The FetchGroup name has to be defined as [FetchField(groupName)] at the field of a class that you want to fetch. FetchPlan.Default or FetchPlan.All is also possible.
member.returns: Returns the changed FetchPlan. You can call: scope.FetchPlan.Set("grp0").Add("grp1").Add("grp2")... several times.
member.remarks:
If you want to use one specific FetchGroup name. This is simliar to call scope.FetchPlan.Clear().Add(groupName)
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.Set(System.String[])
member.summary: Replaces the actual FetchPlan by an string array of FetchGroup names.
member.param: The FetchGroup names has to be defined as [FetchField(groupName)] at the field of a class that you want to fetch. FetchPlan.Default or FetchPlan.All is also possible.
member.returns: Returns the changed FetchPlan. You can call: scope.FetchPlan.Set(groupName).Add("grp1").Remove("grp2")... several times.
member.remarks:
You can make a copy of your FetchPlan definition by calling Groups and Set that Group later.
It is recommended to use symbolic constants for the names of the FetchGroups. This avoids hard to find problems with misspelled values.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.GetGroupNames
member.summary: Gets the actual FetchPlan definition.
member.remarks: You can make a copy of your FetchPlan definition by calling GetGroupNames and Set that Group later.
member.returns: The FetchGroup names have to be defined as [FetchField(groupName)] at the field of a class that you want to fetch. FetchPlan.Default or FetchPlan.All is also possible.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string that represents the current FetchPlan.
member.returns: A that represents the current FetchPlan.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.Limit
member.summary: Controls the maximum number of objects that can be fetched together.
member.remarks: The default value is . If you are traversing a very big tree, you can specify a FetchPlan that retrieves the complete tree and only limit the number of objects by this value.
member.value: An integer >=0. 0 means no limit! The default value is .

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.FetchPlan.MaxDepth
member.summary: Controls the maximum tree depth that is fetched together.
member.remarks:
The value must be >=1.
If you want to fetch a deep tree, you have to set the MaxDepth and also the Depth argument at the [FetchField(groupName,Depth=3)] attribute.
The maximum possible value depends on the database server and the class hierarchy depth and is bound by the number of SQL joins required!
member.value: An integer >=1. Default is .

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.IDBObjectEnumerator
member.summary: Interface for enumerators on persistent database objects.

remarks.para: In general, instances of this type will work using the database object ID.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.IMovableEnumerator
member.summary: Interface for enumerator objects which can be positioned freely.

remarks.para: Instances of this type need to be disposed to release the resources used.
Instances of this type can be obtained from the method.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IMovableEnumerator.Move(System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves the enumerator forwards or backwards by a specified number of elements.
member.param: If greater 0, the enumerator is moved forwards by the specified number of elements. If less than 0, the enumerator is moved backwards.
member.remarks: If the enumerator cannot be positioned, false is returned and the position of the enumerator is undefined. The current object will be undefined as well. This might occur when the resulting position would be before the beginning or behind the end of the underlying collection.
member.returns: Returns true if the enumerator was successfully moved to an object; false if the enumerator could not be positioned.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IMovableEnumerator.MoveToEnd
member.summary: Moves the enumerator behind the last object.
member.remarks: The enumerator will be positioned at a virtual position and the next action needs to be Move(-1) to access the last object.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IMovableEnumerator.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of objects of the underlying source of this enumerator.
member.remarks: The number might change independently when other transactions modify the database concurrently.
member.value: Number of objects.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IDBObjectEnumerator.MoveToObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Moves the enumerator to the specified persistent object.
member.remarks:
If the enumerator cannot find the object, the position will be changed to a virtual position between two objects and is therefore not defined; the current object will also be undefined. In general, you will need to position further using the method. The next object returned will be the object behind (in direction towards the end) the object searched if Move(1) is used. If Move(-1) is used, the previous object is returned. The same holds true if the beginning or end of the underlying collection is reached.
If the enumerator cannot find the value, the possible reasons are:
The object has been deleted in the mean time.
The object was not stored yet.
member.param: The persistent object to move to.
member.returns: Returns true if the enumerator was successfully moved to the object (the object was found); false if the enumerator could not be positioned.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IDBObjectEnumerator.MoveToObject(Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectId)
member.summary: Moves the enumerator to the persistent object with the specified database object id.
member.param: The id of the persistent object to move to.
member.remarks:
If the enumerator cannot find the oid value, the position will be changed to a virtual position between two objects and is therefore not defined; the current object will also be undefined. In general, you will need to position further using the method. The next object returned will be the object behind (in direction towards the end) the object searched if Move(1) is used. If Move(-1) is used, the previous object is returned. The same holds true if the beginning or end of the underlying collection is reached.
If the enumerator cannot find the value, the possible reasons are:
The object has been deleted in the mean time.
The object was not stored yet.
member.returns: Returns true if the enumerator was successfully moved to the object (the object was found); false if the enumerator could not be positioned.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.IInstanceCallbacks
member.summary: Interface that provides callback methods for life cycle events of persistent objects.

remarks.para: Persistence-capable classes which include non-persistent fields whose values depend on the values of persistent fields require callbacks on specific life cycle events in order to correctly populate the values of these fields.
This interface defines the methods executed by the for these life cycle events. The persistent object must implement the methods to get called back.
When used in conjunction with an object context, no instance callbacks are generated currently.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IInstanceCallbacks.PostLoad
member.summary: Called after the persistent values are loaded from the database into this instance.
member.remarks: Transient fields should be initialized in this method. The context in which this call is made does not allow access to other persistent instances.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IInstanceCallbacks.PreRemove(Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope)
member.summary: Called before the instance is removed.
member.remarks: This method is called before the state transitions to 'removed' during Access to field values within this call are valid. Access to field values after this call are disallowed.
member.param: The object scope where the change occures.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IInstanceCallbacks.PreStore
member.summary: Called before the values are stored from this instance to the database.
member.remarks: Database stored (persistent) fields that might have been affected by modified non-persistent fields should be updated in this method.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext
member.summary: Common interface of IObjectScope and ObjectContainer.

remarks.para: This interface lists all common database object operations for and .

Methods executed on an will be bound to the transaction boundaries and will affect the state in the database when the transaction is committed, whereas methods of an do not obey transactions (as there is no transaction concept in the ObjectContainer - offline usage intended) and will not alter the state of the persistent objects in the database directly.
An cannot dynamically resolve a database object ID when the persistent object is not contained in the container.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.Add(System.Object)
member.summary: Marks an object of a persistence-capable class to be added to the database context.

remarks.para: Assigns a new database object ID to the instance and transitions it to persistent-new.
After calling this method, the added object will have a database object ID which can be retrieved using .
The instance will be accessible by queries or by with the assigned object ID.

The instance will be put into the database at a successful
of the current transaction. The closure of instances of persistent classes reachable from persistent fields will be made persistent at commit. This is also known as persistence-by-reachability.
Only instances of persistence-capable classes can be added to an IObjectContext.
A class is made persistence-capable using the [Persistent] attribute and the Telerik.OpenAccess .NET enhancer.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.
The persistence capable object can be added a second time to the same IObjectContext without exception (it's not an error, but also unnecessary).
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance.
An instance of a persistence capable class can belong to only one IObjectContext at a given time.

member.param: Instance of a persistence capable class. It can also be an IEnumerable of objects to add.
member.exception: The type of was not marked as [Persistent] or was not enhanced.
Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.Remove(System.Object)
member.summary: Marks an object from this context as 'deleted' and to be removed from the database.

remarks.para: The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.
Objects marked as 'deleted' will be deleted from the database later during (IObjectScope) or will be marked as deleted in the target context during (ObjectContainer).
Unlike the method, which makes the closure of the instance persistent, the closure of the persistent object is not deleted from the database and objects will be deleted 'flat' only.
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance.
This method has no effect if the persistent object is already removed in the current transaction.

member.param: Persistent object which must be known to the context before. It can also be an IEnumerable of objects to remove.
member.exception: Instance not known in this context (is transient or managed by another object context).
Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).
The type of was not marked as [Persistent] or is not enhanced.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.MakeDirty(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Marks a field of an object from this context manually as 'dirty' and to be updated in the database context. Must be called before modifications occur.
member.remarks:
Change tracking is normally done automatically. That means, that any writing access to a field of a persistent object will mark the persistent object as dirty; this will cause the update of the values of the persistent object in the database.
This method must be called BEFORE the modifications occur.
Object fields marked as 'dirty' will be stored later during (IObjectScope) or will be modified in the target context during (ObjectContainer).
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.
member.param: The object that should be marked as dirty. It can also be an IEnumerable of objects to mark as dirty.
The field that should be marked as dirty.
member.exception: Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).
The type of was not marked as [Persistent] or is not enhanced.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.IsDirty(System.Object)
member.summary: Indicates whether the state of a persistent object in this context is 'dirty' / to be updated.

remarks.para: A persistent object is of dirty state when the value of at least one persistent field was changed. When the current transaction commits, the database will be updated with the changed values.
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.

member.param: The object to be checked.
member.returns: true if the object was modified (marked as dirty); false otherwise.
member.exception: The type of was not marked as [Persistent] or is not enhanced.
Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.IsDirty(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Indicates whether the state of a field of a persistent object in this context is 'dirty' / to be updated.

remarks.para: A field is of dirty state when the value of the persistent field was changed. When the current transaction commits, the database will be updated with the changed values.
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.

member.param: The object to be checked.
The name of the field to be checked
member.returns: true if the object was modified (marked as dirty); false otherwise.
member.exception: The type of was not marked as [Persistent] or is not enhanced.
Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.IsRemoved(System.Object)
member.summary: Indicates whether the state of a persistent object in this context is 'deleted' / to be deleted.

remarks.para: A persistent object is of marked-as-to-be-removed state when it was marked as to be removed but the transaction was not successfully committed yet.
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.

member.param: The object to be checked.
member.returns: true if the object was deleted (marked as deleted); false otherwise.
member.exception: The type of was not marked as [Persistent] or is not enhanced.
Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.IsNew(System.Object)
member.summary: Indicates whether the state of a persistent object in this context is 'new' / to be inserted.

remarks.para: A persistent object is of state new when it is not stored in the database yet. A persistent (or more correct: an instance of a persistence-capable class) object becomes persistent when the transaction terminates successfully via .
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.

member.param: The object to be checked.
member.returns: true if the object was added (marked as added); false otherwise.
member.exception: The type of was not marked as [Persistent] or is not enhanced.
Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.IsHollow(System.Object)
member.summary: Indicates whether an object is hollow, i.e., its content is empty and not yet filled from the database.

remarks.para: If a persistent object of hollow state is accessed (by reading or writing a field), its values are retrieved from the database and the state changes to clean (read access) or dirty (write access). If the object is not accessible (deleted, locked or not authorized), an exception will be thrown.
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance. Hollow instances cannot be deferred-loaded from the database when using a disconnected .
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.

member.param: The object where the hollow state should be returned for.
member.returns: Returns true if the object is hollow; otherwise false.
member.exception: The type of was not marked as [Persistent] or is not enhanced.
Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.GetObjectId(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the database identity for a persistent object.

remarks.para: Changing the returned instance will not affect the database identity for .
The persistent object can be retrieved later using the returned instance using the method.
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance. For newly added instances, the database object identity might be a temporary one.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.

member.param: The instance whose identity is requested.
member.returns: The database object ID of the instance or null if does not belong to this context or is not enhanced.
member.exception: Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.GetObjectById(Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectId)
member.summary: Retrieves the instance which is associated with the given database object ID from this context.

remarks.para: The method attempts to find an instance in the context with the specified database object ID.
The parameter object might have been returned by an earlier call to , or might have been provided by the application using a new object.
No change will be made to the state of the returned instance.
If the persistent object with the specified object ID is already in the context, its reference will be returned.
If there is no instance in the context with the same database identity as the parameter, then this method creates an instance with the specified database object ID and returns it.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.
Refer to the description of when using a disconnected instance. Persistent objects cannot be resolved dynamically, when the ObjectContainer does not contain them already.

member.returns: The instance with the specified .
member.param: The database identity object.
member.exception: The object is deleted.
Transaction is not running (IObjectScope implementation).

If there is no instance in the context with the same database identity as the parameter, then this method creates an instance with the specified database object ID and returns it.
The implementation of this method requires that it be called in an active transaction.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectContext.Evict(System.Object)
member.summary: Marks a persistent object as no longer needed in the transaction cache. This is a hint to the implementation.
member.remarks:
Eviction is normally done automatically by the
upon transaction completion (commit or rollback). This method allows the application to explicitly provide a hint that the instance is no longer needed in the transaction cache.
Only non modified old objects can be evicted.
If object is of type , all instances referenced by the enumerator are evicted.
member.param: The instance to evict from the cache. It can also be an IEnumerable of objects to evict.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope
member.summary: Primary interface for database applications and the entry point for executing queries, extent and transaction operations containing methods to manage the life cycle of persistent objects.
member.remarks:
Instances of this type can be obtained from the Database.GetObjectScope methods and represents a connection to the database.
Instances of this type serve as factories for and
objects.
An instance of this type provides access to persistent objects. Persistent objects are instances of enhanced classes marked with the [Persistent] attribute. Each persistent object is associated with a unique database object ID. In every IObjectScope, there can be only one instance with a given database object ID.
The IObjectScope interface is used for working with an online database. The implements the common interface as well and is intended for working disconnected from a database.
IObjectScope instances must be disposed to free the resources after usage.
member.example: An example on the basic operations of the IObjectScope can be found here.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope.Refresh(System.Object)
member.summary: Refreshes the state and values of the persistent object from the database.

remarks.para: The state of the database object might have changed, while the in-memory object does not reflect this change. This method synchronizes the states, so that the in-memory object refreshes its data from the current database object.
When pessimistic concurrency control with repeatable read is used, explicit synchronization is never necessary, because the locking mechanism prevents concurrent changes to the database object.

member.param: The instance to refresh or an IEnumerable of instances to refresh.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope.GetOqlQuery(System.String)
member.summary: Makes a new oql query object from the specified expression.

remarks.para: Using this method, oql queries can be executed in the scope of the object scope and its current transaction.
The provided query expression parameter has to be in oql syntax. An example for an oql expression is "SELECT * FROM AddressExtent AS a WHERE a.street = $1".

member.returns: Returns a query instance, which can be executed.
member.param: The oql query expression.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope.GetOqlQuery``1
member.summary: Makes a new oql query object from the specified type.

remarks.para: Using this method, all instances of the specified types can be returned.
Internally this is replaced by and OQL expression "SELECT * FROM 'T'Extent".

member.returns: Returns a query instance, which can be executed.
member.typeparam: The type of the objects to query for.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope.GetOqlQuery``1(System.String)
member.summary: Makes a new oql query object from the specified expression.

remarks.para: Using this method, oql queries can be executed in the scope of the object scope and its current transaction.
The provided query expression parameter has to be in oql syntax. An example for an oql expression is "SELECT * FROM AddressExtent AS a WHERE a.street = $1".

member.param: The oql query expression.
member.returns: Returns a query instance, which can be executed.
member.exception: Result type of the OQL query and T do not match.
member.typeparam: The type of the objects to return.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope.GetSqlQuery``1(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Makes a new sql query object from the specified expression.

remarks.para: Using this method, native sql queries can be executed in the scope of the object scope and its current transaction.

The provided query expression parameter has to be in sql syntax and is directly passed to the database backend, when the query is executed. An example for a sql statement is "SELECT address_id, city_id, street FROM address WHERE street = ? ".
When calling stored procedure provide the stored procedure name, followed by a comma separated list of the parameters as in the following example: "sp_tables ?,?,?,?"

The type of the result instances can be specified with the generic parameter. If a persistence-capable class is specified as result type, the columns selected in the sql statement must at least contain the primary key columns of the mapped result class, and additionally the discriminator column if defined and the version column(s) if defined.

For each parameter in the query expression, the param parameter has to contain its declaration, e.g. param="VARCHAR p1" for the sql query expression in the example above, or "VARCHAR table_name,VARCHAR table_owner,VARCHAR table_qualifier,VARCHAR table_type" for the stored procedure call in the example above. For stored procedures the specified parameter names must be the same as the parameter names in the stored procedure declaration.

member.param: The sql query expression.
The parameter declarations for the sql expression.
member.returns: Returns a query instance, which can be executed.
member.typeparam: The type of the returned objects.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope.GetOqlQuery(Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery)
member.summary: Makes a new oql query object from an exististing query.

remarks.para: This method can be used, if an existing query shall be executed in the context of an object scope different from the object scope where the query was originally created.
If the original query has already been compiled, the newly created query takes over the compiled format and needs not to be compiled again.

member.returns: Returns a query instance, which can be executed.
member.param: The original sql query.

member.exception: is null.
is closed or disposed.
The had an incorrect value.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope.GetSqlQuery(System.String,System.Type,System.String)
member.summary: Makes a new sql query object from the specified expression.

remarks.para: Using this method, native sql queries can be executed in the scope of the object scope and its current transaction.

The provided query expression parameter has to be in sql syntax and is directly passed to the database backend, when the query is executed. An example for a sql statement is "SELECT address_id, city_id, street FROM address WHERE street = ? ".
When calling stored procedure provide the stored procedure name, followed by a comma separated list of the parameters as in the following example: "sp_tables ?,?,?,?"

The type of the result instances can be specified with the result parameter. If null is specified, System.Object[] arrays are returned, with one array element for each column in the result set. If a persistence-capable class is specified as result type, the columns selected in the sql statement must at least contain the primary key columns of the mapped result class, and additionally the discriminator column if defined and the version column(s) if defined.

For each parameter in the query expression, the param parameter has to contain its declaration, e.g. param="VARCHAR p1" for the sql query expression in the example above, or "VARCHAR table_name,VARCHAR table_owner,VARCHAR table_qualifier,VARCHAR table_type" for the stored procedure call in the example above. For stored procedures the specified parameter names must be the same as the parameter names in the stored procedure declaration.

member.param: The sql query expression.
The type of the instances returned in the query result after query execution.
The parameter declarations for the sql expression.
member.returns: Returns a query instance, which can be executed.

member.summary: Makes a new sql query object from an exististing query.

If the original query has already been compiled, the newly created query takes over the compiled format and needs not to be compiled again.

The parameter object might have been returned by an earlier call to , or might have been provided by the application using a new object.
No change will be made to the state of the returned instance.

If there is no instance in the context with the same database identity as the parameter, then a null is returned and no attempt to load it from the database or second level cache is made.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope.GetOriginalValue``1(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Returns the original value of the named property of field from the persistent object.

remarks.para: If a property or field in a persistent type is changed or marked as dirty, the original value might be of interest. This method can be used to access the original value if it is available.

Per default only the original values for types marked with concurrency mode are kept. If all original values are of interest, the context.ContextProperties.MaintainOriginalValues property has to be set to true.
To keep all original values in memory might have an memory overhead. If one field is made dirty, all fields of that respective type are stored in an extra object[].
If the object is new, the default value of the respective property type is returned. If the property or field is clean, the clean value is returned.

member.typeparam: The type of the expected return value. Object can be used for untyped access.
member.param: The object holding the field or property of interest.
The name of the property or field of interest.
member.returns: The old value if it was available and the property or field was dirty, the actual value otherwise.
member.exception: If one of the arguments is null or string.Empty
If the entity is not managed by this context.
If the no property or field with the specified name can be found.
If the original value is not available.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery
member.summary: Interface for executing queries.
member.remarks:
An instance of this interface can be obtained from the IObjectScope.GetOqlQuery or
IObjectScope.GetSqlQuery methods.
Queries are always executed in an actual transaction context.
Instances of this class represent OQL or SQL queries.
An OQL-query can contain parameters in its WHERE-clause, that have to be suplied later for execution. Parameters are marked with $1, $2, ... in the query expression and must be matched with the parameter values during query execution.
The query execution is deferred until the result enumerator is used to retrieve the first result object.
Please see the Telerik.OpenAccess .NET OQL reference for more information about the OQL syntax.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.Compile
member.summary: Compiles the query to the native query format, e.g. SQL.
member.remarks: If Compile has not been called before is called, Execute will call Compile implicitely.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.Execute
member.summary: Executes the specified query and returns the result. This method can only be used for queries without parameters.
member.returns: The result of the query execution.
member.remarks: The returned result object needs to be disposed.

member.summary: Executes the specified query using the parameters passed and returns the result.
member.param: The query parameters to use.
member.returns: The result of the query execution.
member.remarks: The returned result object needs to be disposed.

member.summary: Executes the specified query using the parameters passed and deletes resulting instances on server only.
member.param: The query parameters to use.

member.summary: Executes the specified query using the parameters passed and updates the resulting instances on server only.
member.param: The query parameters to use.
member.returns: The result of the query execution.
member.remarks: The execution is done server side only.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.Prefetch(System.Int32)
member.summary: Applies prefetch settings to the uncompiled query.
member.remarks:
Prefetching describes the number of objects that are fetched in advance during client/server mode while using an Enumerator.
Notice, that by default read-locks are applied to these objects.
The Prefetch method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.
Allowed values are 0 to 32767, the default value is 0.
member.param: The prefetch value to be used.
member.returns: The query with applied prefetch settings.
member.exception: Query result has already been calculated.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.ForwardsOnly
member.summary: Determines whether the query result can be traversed forwards only, or if random access is possible.
member.remarks:
This property is only an optimization hint. Also with ForwardsOnly==true, random access might be possible.
This method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.
member.value: True, if the query result can be traversed. forwards only

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.IgnoreUncommitted
member.summary: This property determines whether the query execution is allowed to ignore the changes made in the current transaction, e.g. return objects which have been deleted in the current transaction.
member.remarks:
This property is only an optimization hint. Also with IgnoreCache==false, uncommitted data might be considered by the query.
This method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.
Persistence by reachability is maintained for the time of Flush(), but not for the time of Commit().
member.value: True, if uncommitted changes can be ignored.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.MaxResultCount
member.summary: Limits the maximum number of instances to return by query execution. result.
member.remarks:
This property can be used for performance optimizations, if not all instances matching the query are required.
This method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.
member.value: The maximum number of instances to return by query execution.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.Expression
member.summary: Provides the query expression from which this query was created.
member.value: The query expression.
member.remarks: The returned value is the value as given from the application; query parameters will not be resolved yet.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.BackendQuery
member.summary: Gets the generated backend query expression (e.g. SQL).
member.remarks: The returned value may depend on the values of the query parameters. A backend that does not use string representation for the query language will return null.
member.value: The native query expression.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.RootType
member.summary: Gets the root type of the query result when the query returns only instances of a persistence-capable classes.
member.remarks: The returned type is the common type of all returned persistence-capable instances (enhanced classes). If no common type exists (for example by use of a projection), null is returned.
member.value: The root type of the instances delivered by this query, or null.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.ParallelFetch
member.summary: Controls whether parallel result fetching is allowed.
member.remarks: Parallel fetching allows the use of multiple result sets in a combined way for an improved performance at the possible expense of more data beeing fetched.
member.value: True when parallel result fetching is allowed, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery.Skip
member.summary: Controls the amount of data which is to be skipped before results are fetched.
member.remarks:
Together with this method can be used to implement paging.
This method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQueryResult
member.summary: Result of a database query execution. The result has to be disposed.

remarks.para: Instances of this type can be obtained from the IQuery.Execute methods.
Instances of this type must be disposed to free underlying resources. The result object itself and all enumerator objects for it become invalid, the contained objects itself remain valid.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQueryResult.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns a moveable enumerator to enumerate the query result objects.
member.remarks: IMovableEnumerator instances can be used to move freely in the underlying collection.

member.returns: See
member.param: See

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQueryResult.GetTotalCount
member.summary: Obtains the total number of results in a paging-independend fashion.

remarks.para: The purpose of this method is to obtain the total number of results prior to enumerating the result itself in a paging-independend fashion (e.g. the overall number of results, not the number of results in the page).
This method will execute a seperate, optimized auxilliary query when the value of the property of the generating instance had been set to True.

member.returns: The total number of results.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQueryResult.ToList

member.remarks: To free memory and server side resources the call to ToList will close the query result.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.IQueryResult.OutParameter

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking
member.summary: Provides change tracking events for modifications of persistent objects.
member.remarks:
This interface provides events which can be used to get track changes on persistent objects. Such events can be used to implement custom change tracking models.
An instance of this interface is always bound to one or instance. It can be obtained from the property.

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking.Changing
member.summary: Occurs before a field of a persistent object is changed by the application.
member.remarks:
The Changing event is raised before the new value of a field is assigned to the field.
It is possible to avoid the assignment by throwing an exception.
member.example: Please refer to the example of .

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking.Changed
member.summary: Occurs after a field of a persistent object has been changed by the application.
member.remarks: The Changed event is raised after the new value of a field has been assigned to the field.
member.example: Please refer to the example of .

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking.Adding
member.summary: Occurs before a persistent object is added to the object context.
member.remarks:
The Adding event is raised before the object is added to an instance.
It is possible to avoid the persisting of an object by throwing an exception.
Please note, that the retrieval of the (possibly database-assigned) object identity is not possible before the object is actually known to the object context. When this object identity retrieval is required, the event should be used.
member.example: Please refer to the example of .

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking.Added
member.summary: Occurs after an object was marked as to be persisted by the object context.
member.remarks: The Added event is raised after the persistent object has been added to the .
member.example: Please refer to the example of .

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking.Removing
member.summary: Occurs before a persistent object is removed from the object context.
member.remarks:
The Removing event is raised before the object is removed the instance.
It is possible to avoid the deletion of a persistent object by throwing an exception.
member.example: Please refer to the example of .

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking.Removed
member.summary: Occurs after a persistent object was marked as to be removed from the object context.
member.remarks:
The Removed event is raised after the persistent object has been removed from the .
Please note, that an access of the field values of a removed persistent object is not possible. When this access is required, the event should be used.
member.example: Please refer to the example of .

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking.Refreshing
member.summary: Occurs before a persistent object is refreshed from the database.
member.remarks:
The Refreshing is raised occurs before the object is reloaded from the database.
It is possible to avoid the refreshing of a persistent object by throwing an exception.
member.example: Please refer to the example of .

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITracking.Refreshed
member.summary: Occurs after a persistent object was refreshed from the database.
member.remarks: The Refreshed event is raised after the persistent object has been refreshed from the database.
member.example: Please refer to the example of .
