member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.LockMode
member.summary: Specification of a pessimistic lock.

remarks.para: Can be used independent of TransactionMode setting.
Values of this type can be used to specify the lock mode during ITransaction.Lock.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.LockMode.READ
member.summary: Locks for read access. This is a shared lock, it conflicts with exclusive locks of other transactions.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.LockMode.WRITE
member.summary: Locks for write access. This is an exclusive lock, it conflicts with any locks of other transactions. It also inhibits write or delete operations of other transactions.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.LockMode.DELETE
member.summary: deprecated; behaves identical like WRITE

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction
member.summary: Database transaction interface.

remarks.para: Instances of this interface can be obtained from the IObjectContext.Transaction property, which will always contain the current transaction of the .
The properties of a database transaction can be specified using the property.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.Begin
member.summary: Begins a new transaction. If there is another transaction already running an exception will be thrown.

remarks.para: Begin marks the start of a transaction level.
If this is a transaction bound to an , the current values of the are used for the transaction.

member.exception: Concurrency property is wrong.
Associated IObjectScope object was disposed.
Using System.Transactions prohibits this method.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.Commit
member.summary: Commits the transaction on the current nesting level. In case of exceptions, the transaction is implicitly rolled back.
member.exception: When an unique index is violated.
When there is a insufficient disk space condition or a disk writing failure.
When there is an access rights violation.
When a concurrency control conflict occured.
Transaction was not started before.
Using System.Transactions prohibits this method.
member.remarks:
Commit marks the end of a transaction level. If Commit fails, the database is not modified and the transaction level is implicitly rolled back.
The database is only modified by a successful Commit.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.Rollback
member.summary: Rolls back this transaction on the current nesting level.
member.exception: Transaction was not started before.
Using System.Transactions prohibits this method.
member.remarks: Rollback marks the end of a transaction level.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.Flush
member.summary: Flush all dirty and new instances to the database.

remarks.para: If a query or other database operation should take the actual changes into accout a flush can be done. It pushes all changes to the relational server but keep a server side transaction running to be able to rollback later.
Persistence by reachability is maintained for the time of Flush(), but not for the time of Commit().
The provisional persistent objects are also flushed to the database and will not be removed if they are not longer reachable from an already persistent object during commit.

member.exception: Transaction was not started before.
Transaction is not at level 1.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.FlushAndUnmanage
member.summary: Flush all dirty and new instances to the database and evict all instances from the local cache.

remarks.para: This method allows unreferenced instances to be garbage collected making it easier to write loops that update millions of instances in a single transaction.
Persistence by reachability is maintained for the time of Flush(), but not for the time of Commit().
The provisional persistent objects are also flushed to the database and will not be removed if they are not longer reachable from an already persistent object during commit.
All objects are not longer bound to the context. You will get new instances from a following query.
FlushAndUnmanage does not work together with System.Transaction.

member.exception: Transaction was not started before.
Transaction is not at level 1.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.Lock(System.Object,Telerik.OpenAccess.LockMode)
member.summary: Sets a pessimistic lock on the specified object or collection elements. Might throw a LockNotGrantedException.
member.param: The persistent object to be locked or an ICollection containing persistent objects to be locked.
The lock to be applied.
member.exception: When the specified lock could not be obtained.
Transaction was not started before.

remarks.para: This method allow the usage of pessimistic locks within optimistic transactions.

If an instance of type is passed as , all elements will be locked with the . The elements must be persistent objects. If the lock cannot be obtained for one element of the collection, the already locked objects will remain locked and the objects not processed yet will not be locked.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.GetDirtyObjects``1
member.summary: Returns all objects of the specified type which have been modified in the transaction.
member.value: An instance of System.Colections.Generic.IListThe type of the objects to be returned. containing all updated, deleted and newly inserted objects of the specified type.
member.remarks:
Removing objects from the returned list will not remove them from the transaction change set.
Type of the dirty instances

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.Objects``1(Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectState)
member.summary: Returns a read-only snapshot view of all objects of the specified type and state.
member.remarks:
This method behaves differently between and :
For the , only objects of the current transaction are returned. It is not possible to obtain all Clean and Hollow objects; an exception will be thrown when this is attempted.
With the , objects of the ObjectContainer are returned; those might come from an earlier transaction in the ObjectContainer. In this case the objects in the ObjectContainer are seen as one transaction content.
You can combine different ObjectState values together (Dirty|New).
member.returns: A read-only snapshot view of all objects of the specified type in the requested state.
member.exception: When an attempt is made to obtain all clean and hollow objects when this is not possible.
member.param: The state of the objects to be returned.
member.typeparam: The type of the objects to be returned.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.IsActive
member.summary: Indicates whether the transaction is currently active, i.e., the transaction has been begun but not yet been committed or rolled back.
member.value: true if transaction is running, false, if transaction is not running
member.remarks: Modifications to the database are only allowed from an active transaction.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.Level
member.summary: Gets the current nesting level of the transaction.
member.value: Current transaction level if transaction is active or 0 if transaction is inactive.
member.remarks: Modifications to the database / container are only allowed from a transaction with level > 0.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.IsDirty
member.summary: Indicates whether modifications (updates, deletes, inserts) have been made in the transaction.
member.value: true, if modifications have been made.
member.remarks: You can use this property to determine if the transaction needs to be committed or if a rollback is sufficient.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.DirtyObjects
member.summary: Returns all objects which have been modified in the transaction.
member.value: An instance of System.Colections.IList containing all updated, deleted and newly inserted objects.
member.remarks: Removing objects from the returned list will not remove them from the transaction change set.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransaction.IsManaged
member.summary: Indicates whether the transaction is managed.
member.remarks: When System.Transactions (from .Net 2 framework) are used, this property returns true.
member.value: true if the transaction is managed; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties
member.summary: Controls the properties of a database transaction.

remarks.para:
An instance of this type can be obtained from the
IObjectScope.TransactionProperties property and controls the settings of the current transaction of the associated . The default transaction properties for the database can be obtained from Database.DefaultTransactionProperties.
The default values are described at the description of the respective property.
The properties of a transaction cannot be changed when the transaction is active (started).

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties.RetainValues
member.summary: Controls whether persistent objects retain their values after commit of the transaction and if read access is allowed. Default is true.
member.value: Default is true.
member.remarks: Regardless of the setting the objects will be refreshed from the database when the object is accessed within an active transaction the next time.
member.exception: Transaction is active.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties.RestoreValues
member.summary: Controls whether the values of persistent objects are restored to their original values when the transaction (or one particular nesting level) is rolled back. Default is false.
member.remarks: If set to true, the values of the persistent fields are restored to their original values.
member.value: Default is false.
member.exception: Transaction is active.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties.Concurrency
member.summary: Controls the concurrency of the transaction. Default is TransactionMode.OPTIMISTIC_NO_LOST_UPDATES.
member.remarks: Default is to use optimistic transactions and to prevent lost updates ()
member.value: Default is TransactionMode.OPTIMISTIC_NO_LOST_UPDATES.
member.exception: Transaction is active.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties.RefreshReadObjectsInNewTransaction
member.summary: Determines, whether objects that were read (but not modified) in a previous transaction are refreshed upon the first access in a subsequent transaction. Default is True; use with care!

remarks.para: The default is true, and this setting should only be changed with great care, as setting it to false might result in long-living stale objects.
If setting this option to false the user is responsible to refresh read objects that are possible stale in subsequent transactions of the same IObjectScope.

Note, that the default value of true does not guarantee non-stale objects when using optimistic transactions. It does only guarantee, that objects used in previous transactions are refreshed on the first read access in subsequent transactions of the same IObjectScope.

member.value: Default is true.
member.exception: Transaction is active.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties.AutomaticBegin
member.summary: Determines, whether a transaction is always active (automatically started).

remarks.para: When set to true, the transaction will automatically started during a or . Additionally, the transaction is immediately made active when required.
When set to false, the transaction is not automatically starting (any more) and the application must make calls to . The transaction is not finished by setting the property to false.

Setting this property to true is useful under two circumstances:
You are forced to program in a similiar way as on a SQL connection.
You are working in a multithreaded environment and need to execute / and in one synchronized atomic operation.
Using on an with an active transaction will rollback that transaction; make sure that all changes are committed before disposing the object scope.
Setting the property to true in a managed transaction environment is not allowed and will result in an exception.

member.value: The default is false.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties.FailFast
member.summary: Determines, whether a transaction commit or flush should fail on the first failure.

remarks.para: When set to true, the transaction will fail on occurence of the first . When set to false the commit or flush will continue and collect all that occur.
Value false should only be used if the information about the failing objects is necessary.
Attention: To collect all failures can be very time consuming!

member.value: The default is true.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties.ReadAfterDelete
member.summary: Controls whether the values of persistent objects are accessible when the object is marked for deletion. Default is false.
member.remarks:
If set to true, the values of the persistent fields are readable even if the object is marked for deletion by using or .
The values are only available in the actual transaction. If the transaction is committed or flushed the deleted object's fields are cleared. The object should no longer be used because it is in an invalid state.
member.value: Default is false.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.ITransactionProperties.EnableDataSynchronization
member.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that determines whether the context behaves in data synchronization mode when it executes Insert and Update operations. If the Telerik.OpenAccess.OpenAccessContextBase is in this mode, the DateTime and version fields that are automatically set by OpenAccess will not be calculated.
member.returns: A value that is true when data synchronization mode is enabled; otherwise false.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer

summary.para: Implementation of a container for networks of persistent objects which are disconnected from a database. The ObjectContainer implements change tracking and can be used later to reapply the offline changes to a database.

remarks.para:
Because the is not associated with a
object it does not provide a transaction concept and is unable to obtain connected objects like . The
keeps track of all contained persistent objects and their modifications.

The change tracking of the implements the states DETACHED, CLEAN, DIRTY, DELETED and NEW. The states are connected like this:
Original State Method Target State
IObjectScope Object ---> CopyFrom() ---> CLEAN | DETACHED new Object ---> Add() ---> NEW NEW ---> ChangeObjectId() ---> DIRTY CLEAN ---> MakeDirty() ---> DIRTY CLEAN ---> Remove() ---> DELETED DIRTY | DETACHED ---> Remove() ---> DELETED NEW ---> Remove() ---> -

The initial filling of the can be done using existing objects from a and the method. New persistent objects can also be added into the with the
method and get a temporary object ID which is valid within the used container.

When the changed content needs to be made available to the , a target can be updated with the content using the method. In order to detect concurrent changes, a verification step is made which verifies all persistent objects marked with [Persistent] as Verifiable.
If the verification detects a concurrency conflict, the method will fail with an exception and the ObjectContainer will need to be modified by the application until the verification succeeds. This can be accomplished using an to retrieve the actual values and merging those values to the ObjectContainer manually in an application specific manner. Another approach is to abandon the current values of the ObjectContainer and repeat the operations in a new ObjectContainer (filled with the correct current values from the database).

The implements a simple way to mark objects for later simplified retrieval. Objects can be put into a 'named list'. Named lists can be enumerated separately and might be useful to hold application specific root objects. It is intended, that the root objects are used as business-objects.
ObjectContainer instances can be serialized and will include the persistent objects contained objects in them.

member.summary: Inserts an object of a persistence-capable class into this ObjectContainer.
member.remarks:
The object to be inserted must not belong to any
or before.
The class of the object must be declared as persistent.
The object will be added with the state 'NEW' if it was not available in the container before; otherwise the state is maintained.
The ObjectContainer instance must not be read-only.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.Remove(System.Object)
member.summary: Marks a persistent object as deleted.
member.remarks:
When updating the database with this ObjectContainer, the corresponding object will be permanently deleted from the database upon successful commit. Deleting detached (hollow) objects is allowed. The removed object will go to state 'DELETED'.
When the removed instance is new, the instance is evicted from the ObjectContainer.
The persistent object must be contained in this ObjectContainer. The instance must not be read-only.
member.param: The object to be removed from the ObjectContainer. It can also be an IEnumerable of objects to remove.
member.exception: When is not contained in this ObjectContainer.
When this instance is set to read-only.

member.summary: Marks the field of a persistent object explicitly as dirty. Must be called before modifications occur.

remarks.para: When updating the database with this ObjectContainer, the corresponding object will be modified.
This method must be called before modifications occur.
The ObjectContainer will be notified implicitly for all modifications of the contained objects (change tracking). The resulting state will be 'DIRTY'.
The persistent object must be contained in this ObjectContainer. The instance must not be read-only.

member.param: The persistent object to be marked as dirty. It can also be an IEnumerable of objects to mark as dirty.
The field of the persistent object to be marked as dirty.
member.exception: When is not contained in this ObjectContainer.
When this instance is set to read-only.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.CopyFrom(Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope,System.String,System.Object,Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectCollector)
member.summary: Creates a copy of each specified persistent root object and adds it to the ObjectContainer.
member.remarks:
This method can be used to create a copy of objects in an object scope, and add these copies to the container. The parameter specifies the 'root objects' that are to be added to the container. All the root objects are added to a 'named list'. This list can be used to later retrieve the root objects.
The parameter, which is an instance of the interface, can be used to specify that objects referenced by the 'root objects' also need to be copied and added to the container. In this case the 'root objects' are added to both, the named list and the container whereas the referenced objects are added only to the container.
The class provides an implementation of the IObjectCollector interface.
The imported objects will be added into the state 'CLEAN'.
member.param: The source IObjectScope to copy from.
The name of the list under which the added objects should be retrievable.

Persistent object that is to be added to the container. Can also be of type IEnumerable or IEnumerator in which case all contained objects are added to the container.
In the case where a persistent capable class also implements IEnumerable or IEnumerator, the object network for only this class' object is calculated. The contained objects are not enumerated.

An implementation of the IObjectCollector interface used to calculate the object network for each of the root objects.
This parameter can be null, in which case only the root objects are added to the contatiner.
member.exception: When the source scope object is not accessible.
When the source scope transaction mode is pessimistic and the object cannot be locked.
When the source scope object was referenced but is deleted in the database.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.CopyTo(Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope,Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.Verify)
member.summary: Applies the changes contained in this ObjectContainer to the given IObjectScope using a default merge algorithm which failes when a conflict is detected.

remarks.para: This method can be used to replay the changes made offline into a database. It is recommended, that you verify all changed objects with and lock them pessimistically with .
Only objects marked as Verifiable in the [Persistent] attribute will be verified.
The CopyTo method is executed non-atomically; the target IObjectScope might contain modifications when CopyTo is aborted.

Depending on the objects to be copied and the data model used newly created objects might lead to unwanted duplicates; if this needs to be avoided, the new objects from the container must be checked with the current data from the target object scope beforehand.

member.param: The target IObjectScope to copy to.
Specifies which verifiable objects are verified and locked.
member.exception: When the changes stored in the container cannot be applied to the target object scope because the database content was changed concurrently.
When an object could not be accessed from the database.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.CommitChanges(Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.ChangeSet,Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.Verify,Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Commits the changes of an ObjectContainer into a database.

remarks.para: This method can be used to apply the changes of an ObjectContainer into a database using an IObjectScope instance.

This method can be used for two purposes:
Apply changes of an ObjectContainer
Apply changes of an ObjectContainer and generate a ChangeSet instance which allows to source ObjectContainer to become 'clean' again.
The parameter can be used to distinguish between the two purposes.
When an exception occurs during processing, the target scope's transaction can still be active. Therefore you should handle this situation within a finally block.

member.exception: When changes have been made in the database concurrently.
member.param: The extracted changes of an ObjectContainer.
The verification mode to use.
The target scope with inactive transaction.
Controls whether all fields should be overwritten (usually true).
If true, the return value will be calculated; otherwise null is returned.
member.returns: When generateUpdateChanges is true, a change set is generated; otherwise null.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.CopyToWithUpdate(Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope,Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.Verify,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Applies the changes contained in this ObjectContainer to the given IObjectScope using a default merge algorithm which failes when a conflict is detected.
member.remarks:
This method can be used to replay the changes made offline into a database. It is recommended, that you verify all changed objects with and lock them pessimistically with .
Only objects marked as Verifiable in the [Persistent] attribute will be verified.
The CopyTo method is executed non-atomically; the target IObjectScope might contain modifications when CopyTo is aborted.
Depending on the objects to be copied and the data model used the ObjectContainer content will be updated to reflect the changes.
Attention: The same scope has to be used for all following operations. If the scope is not committed to the database the container content does not reflect a committable state. After committing the scope transaction the container should not be used anymore or at least completely refreshed. It might contain old concurrency control information.The verification mode to use.The target scope with inactive transaction.Controls whether all fields should be overwritten (usually true).
When the changes stored in the container cannot be applied to the target object scope because the database content was changed concurrently. When an object could not be accessed from the database.
member.param: true if all fields should be updated
The verification mode to use.
The target scope with inactive transaction.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.CopyTo(Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope,Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.Verify,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Applies the changes contained in this ObjectContainer to the given IObjectScope using a default merge algorithm which failes when a conflict is detected. Can protect attributed object fields from being overwritten with the ObjectContainer content.

remarks.para: This method can be used to replay the changes made offline into a database. It is recommended, that you verify all changed objects with and lock them pessimistically with .
Only objects marked as Verifiable in the [Persistent] attribute will be verified.
The changed/inserted objects will be copied with all field values when is set to true; otherwise, the attribute is obeyed and such attributed fields will not be copied.

The CopyTo method is executed non-atomically; the target IObjectScope might contain modifications when CopyTo is aborted.
Depending on the objects to be copied and the data model used newly created objects might lead to unwanted duplicates; if this needs to be avoided, the new objects from the container must be checked with the current data from the target object scope beforehand.

member.param: The target IObjectScope to copy to.
Specifies which verifiable objects are verified and locked.
Specifies if all object fields are to be copied; if false copies only fields not marked with the attribute.
member.exception: When the changes stored in the container cannot be applied to the target object scope because the database content was changed concurrently.
When an object could not be accessed from the database.

member.summary: Creates a new change set with the actual modifications.

The returned change set instance will contain a serializable copy of all added,modified or deleted objects of this ObjectContainer.

Using the method allows to make the changes of this ObjectContainer persistent in a database. The controls the amount of data in the result; it does not control the verification used during CommitChanges.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.MarkContentAsNew
member.summary: Marks the complete container content as new.
member.remarks: Marking the content as new is useful if the data should be copied from one database to another. The destination database should not contain data with the same primary keys. The data will be handled as new data, it cannot be used for an update process of existing data.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.MarkContentAsClean
member.summary: Marks the complete container content as clean.
member.remarks:
Executing this function will break the synchronization to the scope. It is useful to track changes on objects that you do not want to copy back. Use with care.
Usage Example:
Fill container with new objects.
Call MarkContentAsClean.
Start changing the container content.
Use container.Transaction.DirtyObjects to access the dirty objects.

member.name: E:Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer.ResolveProxy
member.summary: Occurs when the user attempts to access the content of a proxy (hollow) object.

remarks.para: The ResolveProxy event is raised when the user attempts to access the content of a hollow (proxy) object. When a proper handling is made within the event handler, the otherwise resulting exception can be avoided.
When is used and a write access is attempted, the ResolveProxy event occurs after the ChangingEvent and before the ChangedEvent.

Please notice, that modifying an ObjectContainer with is only permitted when no transaction is active. This is to prevent local modifications to be overwritten by a remotely obtained change set. In cases where such modifications are required, the method must be used with a force=true parameter.

member.summary: Creates a new database object identifier from an externalized form.

This method can be used to generate a instance suitable for use with the method.
The parameter must be in the {type}:{key} form. This representation is produced by the method.
This method requires, that references can be resolved by name. When a type cannot be resolved, check that the respective type has been used by the application before.
To obtain an instance of OIDHelper use the property.
member.exception: No external string representation given.
The external string representation could not be parsed.

member.returns: New IObjectId instance.

This method can be used to generate a string suitable for external use (WebService).
The returned string value can be reparsed by the method and has the general form of {type}:{key} where type is a type identifier and key the string representation of the identifying key.
You can obtain an instance of type by using the method.
To obtain an instance of OIDHelper use the property.
member.exception: No oid instance given.

member.returns: Externalized form for the .

member.param: The enhanced object.
member.exception: No instance given.
No persistence capable instance given.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1
member.summary: Class for executing queries.
member.remarks:
Instances of this class represent OQL or SQL queries.
An instance of this interface can be obtained from the IObjectScope.GetOqlQuery<T> or
IObjectScope.GetSqlQuery<T> methods.
Queries are always executed in an actual transaction context.
An OQL-query can contain parameters in its WHERE-clause, that have to be suplied later for execution. Parameters are marked with $1, $2, ... in the query expression and must be matched with the parameter values during query execution.
The query execution is deferred until the result enumerator is used to retrieve the first result object.
Please see the Telerik.OpenAccess .NET OQL reference for more information about the OQL syntax.
member.typeparam: Return type of the executed query.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.#ctor(Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope,Telerik.OpenAccess.IQuery)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.IgnoreUncommitted
member.summary: This property determines whether the query execution is allowed to ignore the changes made in the current transaction, e.g. return objects which have been deleted in the current transaction.
member.remarks:
This property is only an optimization hint. Also with IgnoreCache==false, uncommitted data might be considered by the query.
This method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.
If working in an optimistic scenario this will flush the current changes to the server and keep the database transaction running until the IObjectScope transaction is committed or rollbacked.
Persistence by reachability is maintained for the time of Flush(), but not for the time of Commit().
member.value: True (default), if uncommitted changes can be ignored.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.Skip
member.summary: Controls the amount of data which is to be skipped before results are fetched.
member.remarks:
Together with this method can be used to implement paging.
This method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.
member.value: Amount of data to skip. (Default:0)

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.MaxResultCount
member.summary: Limits the maximum number of instances to return.
member.remarks:
This property can be used for performance optimizations, if not all instances matching the query are required.
This method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.
member.value: The maximum number of instances to return by query execution.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.ParallelFetch
member.summary: Controls whether parallel result fetching is allowed.
member.remarks: Parallel fetching allows the use of multiple result sets in a combined way for an improved performance at the possible expense of more data beeing fetched.
member.value: True when parallel result fetching is allowed, false (default) otherwise.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.Prefetch
member.summary: Applies prefetch settings to the uncompiled query.
member.remarks:
Prefetching describes the number of objects that are fetched in advance during client/server mode while using an Enumerator.
Attention: In a pessimistic concurrency control scenario by default read-locks are applied to these objects.
The Prefetch method must be called before the query is compiled or executed as this setting changes the generated backend query.
Allowed values are 0 to 32767, the default value is 0.
member.value: The prefetch value to be used.
member.returns: The query with applied prefetch settings.
member.exception: Query result has already been calculated.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.BackendQuery
member.summary: Gets the generated backend query expression (e.g. SQL).
member.remarks:
The returned value may depend on the values of the query parameters. A backend that does not use string representation for the query language will return null.
Obtaining the value will currently when parameters are used.
member.value: The native query expression.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.Expression
member.summary: Provides the query expression from which this query was created.
member.value: The query expression.
member.remarks: The returned value is the value as given from the application; query parameters will not be resolved yet.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.Query`1.Context
member.summary: Provides the context (IObjectScope) of the query.
member.value: The context (IObjectScope)
member.remarks: The returned value is the context (IObjectScope) in which scope this query will be executed.

Instances of this type can be obtained from the Query.ExecuteBindingList<T> methods.
This special result type should be used to bind the query result directly to the UI elements
How add and remove functionaliy, f.e. from a GridView is handled is defined via the persistent behavior functionality.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionMode
member.summary: Specification of the concurrency control for a transaction.

remarks.para: Values of this type are used by the ITransactionProperties.Concurrency property. This enum contains all concurrency settings which can be used by a database backend.

In general, there are two main concurency modes, which can both be used within a transaction:
OPTIMISTIC
PESSIMISTIC

Using optimistic transactions will cause the system to implicitly keep track of accessed objects and their modifications. Conflicts throughout the concurrent execution of operations are detected late. Conflicts will lead to an
during .

Using pessimistic transactions locks are set in the database backend when objects are accessed for read or write by a client. Conflicts are detected early and will cause a . For instance, GetObjectById will throw an exception when the object is already locked against reading access by another transaction.

list.item: For optimistic mode, has to be used.
For pessimistic mode, either or has to be used.

remarks.para: With PESSIMISTIC_WRITE_LOCK_WHEN_FETCHED the database automatically applies exclusive locks, when objects are read from the datastore. Locks are released atomically during commit or rollback, respectively.

With PESSIMISTIC_EXPLICIT the database does not apply any exclusive locks automatically before commit. The ITransaction.Lock method can be used to obtain exclusive locks manually. All locks are released atomically during commit or rollback, respectively. Although no automatic locks are set, a write or delete operation of a PESSIMISTIC_EXPLICIT transaction may be inhibited by locks held by other transactions.
For more information please refer to the Open Access .NET Programmers Guide.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionMode.OPTIMISTIC_NO_LOST_UPDATES
member.summary: Commit will verify that modified objects have not been updated by another transaction meanwhile.
member.remarks: Concurrency control happens during transaction commit. Transaction conflicts will be detected during Transaction.Commit() and will cause . Transaction will verify that modified objects have not been updated by another transaction meanwhile. Only available with optimistic transactions.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionMode.PESSIMISTIC_EXPLICIT
member.summary: Write locks have to be set explicitely by ITransaction.Lock().
member.remarks: Concurrency control happens during entire transaction. Transaction conflicts will be detected for all reading/modifying methods and will cause to be thrown. Write locks have to be set explicitely by ITransaction.Lock.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionMode.PESSIMISTIC_WRITE_LOCK_WHEN_FETCHED
member.summary: All Objects are write-locked when fetched from the datastore.
member.remarks: Concurrency control happens during entire transaction. Transaction conflicts will be detected for all reading/modifying methods and will cause to be thrown.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionMode.PESSIMISTIC_WRITE_LOCK_WHEN_FETCHED_FIRST
member.summary: First Object is write-locked when fetched from the datastore.
member.remarks: Concurrency control happens during entire transaction. Transaction conflicts will be detected for all reading/modifying methods and will cause to be thrown.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionProvider
member.summary: Specifies how transactions are provided.

remarks.para:
This enumeration value is used by and defines the providers for transactions. There are three providers which can be used:
Telerik.OpenAccess
TransactionScope
Explicit

Telerik.OpenAccess indicates the usage of built-in database transactions provided by Telerik.OpenAccess. These transactions can be accessed via the property . Telerik.OpenAccess is the default setting.

The values TransactionScope and Explicit require the usage of the namespace . This namespace is supported since .NET 2.0. provides two different transactional programming models:
an implicit model based on the class.
an explicit model using the class or one of its subclasses.
For more information about implicit system transactions see .
For more information about explicit system transactions see .

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionProvider.OpenAccess
member.summary: Use built-in transactions provided by Telerik.OpenAccess. This is the default setting.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionProvider.TransactionScope
member.summary: Use the implicit transactional programming model (TransactionScope).

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionProvider.Explicit
member.summary: Use the explicit transactional programming model.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.TransactionProvider.Automatic
member.summary: Use the actual available transaction.
member.remarks: If a System.Transaction.Current is set it is used, if not the Openaccess Transaction is used.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.SymbolicFieldName
member.summary: This classes defines symbolic name for several internal for Telerik Data Access Runtime fields and columns. These symbolic names are intended to be used as parameters of FieldValue<T> and SetFieldValue<T> extention methods.
member.remarks: The internal fields cannot be set using SetFieldValue<T> extension method!

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.SymbolicFieldName.InternalPrimaryKey
member.summary: Represents the symbolic name for any internal primary key used by an entity. Internal primary keys are the identity mechanism used by Telerik Data Access when no identity is specified by the developer.

remarks.para: Internal primary keys can be extracted as System.Int32, System.Long or types.
Setting the internal primary key using SetFieldValue<T> extension method is not supported.
Getting the internal primary key when using application defined key(s) is not supported.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.SymbolicFieldName.ClassId
member.summary: Represents the symbolic name for the class type discriminator column when the type is part of an inheritance tree.

remarks.para: Class types discriminators can be extracted as System.String or System.Long types.
Setting the class type discriminator using SetFieldValue<T> extension method is not supported.
Getting the class type discriminator when type has no base entity type is not supported.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.SymbolicFieldName.Version
member.summary: Represents the symbolic name for the internal version control column. Internal version control column is the mechanism used by Telerik Data Access to track changes in different concurrency control scenarios.

remarks.para: Internal versioning information can be extracted as System.Short type.
Setting the internal version using SetFieldValue<T> extension method is not supported.
Getting the public or the internal version is supported except when AllChanged mode is configured for the entity type.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ContainerMerger
member.summary: Implements a merge algorithm for a set of objects to be merged from an ObjectContainer to an instance of IObjectScope.

remarks.para: The implemented merge algoritm tries to merge changes made offline from an into an object which is connected online to a .
Objects derived from this class can be used to implement custom merge algorithms. Such algorithms can be useful if an application specific way of dealing with concurrency conflicts does exist.

A concurrency conflict arises, when an object managed by an gets modified in the database and in the
at the same time. Because the managed object is not connected to a
conflict prevention via locking protocol cannot be done. The conflict will be detected, when the content of the is to be copied to the database using the method. However, the object in the database is already modified (hence the conflict) and the modification made in the database is correct. There are several ways to handle this situation:
Throw away the changes made offline in the , creating a new , recreating the offline changes with the new set of objects and try again the . This is the hard but working way.
Try to merge the changes logically from both sides into the database.
Ignoring the conflict, the changes made offline will overwrite the database content.
Because (2) and (3) require special knowledge about the data model and its inherent constraints, only (1) can be made default; this is why a conflict during will prevent the changes to be made into the database using the standard implementation.

In order to support (2) and (3), a customized subclass of is required. This subclass must handle all conflicts and merge every object from the source into the target . The required actions to do this fall in two categories:
Flow control and traversing all objects
Handling a single object

To implement the handling of a single object (possibly type dependend) a customized derivation of class can be used. It will be called back by the used. In order to hold the required information for a given object, helper objects of class are created by the . The helper objects will contain information about the source and target object as well as information about the possible conflict and last but not least the merge state. This merge state will be deciding, if the calling will be successful or not. All persistent objects of the need to be merged and must set their associated field to true.

Instances of type are used to define application specific merge algorithm for a specific type. Telerik Data Access provides a standard algorithm, which will use all fields of the source object and copy them to the target object.
The standard implementation of the is used, when no customized object merger is provided. For protecting fields from overwriting please refer to .

To control the flow control and the merge order of the single objects the can be customized. Customization can be done by overriding virtual methods like and . Several predefined methods (f.e. ) can be used to define a customized traversing strategy and merge handling.
Objects are only subject to verification and concurrent change detection, if they are attributed with Verifiable=true in the .

In order to support advanced merge algorithms where object ID mappings need to be done, an additional step can be made before is called. When calling all objects of the source container with a temporary object ID will be used in the call back of the method. This can be used to new objects before they are merged into a database. Adapting object identifiers needs to be done before the method is run in order to provide the verification step with the correct database object IDs.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ContainerMerger.AdaptIdentifiers(Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer,Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope)
member.summary: Triggers the callback AdaptIdentifier to be called for all persistent objects of an ObjectContainer which have a temporary object ID only.
member.param: The container with the objects having a temporary object ID.
Target IObjectScope of an advanced merge algorithm.
member.remarks: For usage scenario description see .

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ContainerMerger.AdaptIdentifier(System.Object,System.Object,Telerik.OpenAccess.ObjectContainer,Telerik.OpenAccess.IObjectScope)
member.summary: Callback triggered by AdaptIdentifiers (to be overridden by user).
member.param: The object with the temporary object ID.
The referencing object of .
The ObjectContainer managing .
Target IObjectScope of an advanced merge algorithm.
member.remarks:
This callback method is triggered by and allows the implementor to modify the database object ID for all objects of NEW state from the ObjectContainer.
The primary usage scenario for this method is to change the id of objects of an which was filled offline. Filling the container this way will create objects in the NEW state. If the values for the objects come from a source where information about the original database object IDs is available, those newly created objects in the container might need to be renamed before their values are transferred to the database using the method because the real object ID must be known before the object is checked for concurrent modification.
This method is called for all objects of state NEW of the container.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ContainerMerger.CreateObjectMergeInfo(System.Object,System.Exception,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Contructs a new ObjectMergeInfo object.
member.remarks: This callback will be called implicitely for all objects of the source ObjectContainer. User can override this callback to supply a custom merge algorithm specific merge info object.
member.param: The object of the source ObjectContainer to create an ObjectMergeInfo for.
A possible conflict which was detected during the method; can be null.
Indicates a new object.
Indicates a deleted object.
member.returns: New ObjectMergeInfo object for .

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ContainerMerger.MergeAll(System.Collections.ArrayList)
member.summary: Callback to merge all objects, performing MergeAllRootClosures per default.
member.remarks:
This method can be overridden to request a different order during the traversal of all objects of this ObjectContainer. Several methods are predefined and can be used here:
MergeAllNoOrder
MergeAllNewChangedDeletedCleanHollow
MergeAllRootDescending
MergeAllRootClosures
The default method is .
member.param: Internal list with all changes.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ContainerMerger.MergeAllNoOrder
member.summary: Will traverse the whole ObjectContainer in no specific order and will call MergeObject for each element.

remarks.para: This method can be called from to perform a fast merge algorithm if no specific order of the objects is required for merging.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ContainerMerger.MergeAllNewChangedDeletedCleanHollow(System.Boolean,System.Collections.ArrayList)
member.summary: Will traverse the whole source ObjectContainer by iterating all objects based on their state. Will call MergeObject for every object.

remarks.para: This method can be called from to perform a merge algorithm where the object state should decide about the order of the objects being merged.

The objects will be merged by state in the following order:
NEW
DIRTY
DELETED
CLEAN
DETACHED

Using the parameter with value false will prevent objects of CLEAN and DETACHED state being resolved in the target IObjectScope. This can increase performance depending on the usage pattern. This applies only to conflict free objects.

member.param: Value indicating whether objects of CLEAN and DETACHED state must be resolved in the target scope.
Internal list with all changes

member.summary: Callback to handle to merge operation for one object of the source ObjectContainer.

remarks.para: Will first call for objects with a conflict.
Will then call the appropriate method of the object depending on the source context state of the object to be merged.
This method needs to be called for every object of the ObjectContainer. The predefined methods called from will do so.

member.returns: true if the object was merged, false otherwise.

member.summary: This interface is the point of contact between managed instances of PersistenceCapable classes and the JDO implementation. It contains the methods used by PersistenceCapable instances to delegate behavior to the JDO implementation.
member.remarks: Each managed PersistenceCapable instance contains a reference to a StateManager. A StateManager might manage one or multiple instances of PersistenceCapable instances, at the choice of the implementation.

member.summary: Replace the current value of jdoStateManager. This method is called by the PersistenceCapable whenever jdoReplaceStateManager is called and there is already an owning StateManager. This is a security precaution to ensure that the owning StateManager is the only source of any change to its reference in the PersistenceCapable.
member.returns: the new value for the jdoStateManager
member.param: the calling PersistenceCapable instance
the proposed new value for the jdoStateManager

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.StateManager.IsDirty(Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.PersistenceCapable,System.String)
member.summary: Tests whether this object is dirty.
member.remarks:
Instances that have been modified, deleted, or newly made persistent in the current transaction return true.
Transient nontransactional instances return false.
member.param: the calling PersistenceCapable instance
The name of a field that should be check or null for complete object.
member.returns: true if this instance has been modified in the current transaction.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.StateManager.IsTransactional(Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.PersistenceCapable)
member.summary:
Tests whether this object is transactional.
Instances that respect transaction boundaries return true. These instances include transient instances made transactional as a result of being the target of a makeTransactional method call; newly made persistent or deleted persistent instances; persistent instances read in data store transactions; and persistent instances modified in optimistic transactions.
Transient nontransactional instances return false.
member.param: the calling PersistenceCapable instance
member.returns: true if this instance is transactional.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.StateManager.IsPersistent(Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.PersistenceCapable)
member.summary:
Tests whether this object is persistent.
Instances whose state is stored in the data store return true.
Transient instances return false.
member.param: the calling PersistenceCapable instance
member.returns: true if this instance is persistent.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.StateManager.IsNew(Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.PersistenceCapable)
member.summary:
Tests whether this object has been newly made persistent.
Instances that have been made persistent in the current transaction return true.
Transient instances return false.
member.param: the calling PersistenceCapable instance
member.returns: true if this instance was made persistent in the current transaction.

Tests whether this object has been deleted.
Instances that have been deleted in the current transaction return true.
Transient instances return false.
member.param: the calling PersistenceCapable instance

member.summary:
Mark the associated PersistenceCapable field dirty.
The StateManager will make a copy of the field so it can be restored if needed later, and then mark the field as modified in the current transaction.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectListWrapper
member.summary: ObjectListWrapper is a wrapper class for a single persistent object or a collection of persistent objects.
member.remarks: This class also supports access on readonly source collections (delimited). Optionally an IObjectContext can be set, so that an Add/Remove will add it to the context and a Remove will delete it from the context.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo
member.summary: Object specific merge information.

remarks.para: Instances of this class are used to transport object specific information during the merge process performed by .

Instances of this class are only created from the
method. User derived classes can be used during application specific merge algorithms.
This class works in close cooperation with the and classes.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo.from
member.summary: The persistent object from the source context. Cannot be null.
member.remarks: When used by a , this field will hold the object from the source container.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo.to
member.summary: The persistent object from the destination context. Can be null. This object should be the corresponding counterpart of the from object. Usually this means, their database object ID will be equal.
member.remarks: When used by a , this field will hold the object of the target scope.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo.conflict
member.summary: The merge conflict that has been detected (if any). Can be null.
member.remarks: The conflict field will be set if the database backend has detected a conflict. If a conflict is detected, the merge operation will fail if no application-specific handling occures.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo.merged
member.summary: Indicates if the object has been merged.
member.remarks:
This field will be initialized with false and must be set to true to indicate that the object merge was successful.
If this field is not set to true at the end of the entire merge process, the whole merge step will be regarded as failed.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo.isNew
member.summary: Indicates whether an object is new.
member.remarks: This field will be set to true when an object is new in the target scope.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo.isDeleted
member.summary: Indicates whether an object is deleted.
member.remarks: This field will be set to true when an object is deleted in the target scope.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo.#ctor(System.Object,System.Exception,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Contructs a new ObjectMergeInfo instance with initial values.
member.remarks:
Instances of this type are only created from the method. You need to override this method when application specific merge information needs to be managed using derived classes.
Initially, the source context's object is marked as not merged.
member.param: The source context's object.
The merge conflict (if any).
Indicates if object is new.
Indicates if object is deleted.

member.name: P:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo.show
member.summary: Gets debugging information. Format might change any time.
member.remarks:
The meaning of the different characters is as follows:
R Object is marked as root object.
S Object snapshot of previous state is known.
+ Object is resolved in target context.
C A conflict with the values of the database was detected.
TODO This object is not merged yet.
OK This object is marked as merged.
This property should be used for debugging only.
member.value: String value showing the state of the conflict.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger
member.summary: Implements a merge algorithm for a pair of objects.

remarks.para: This class is to be used in close cooperation with and provides callback methods to handle one specific source/target object pair during .
The attribute can be used to mark fields of persistent classes. If such a mark exists, the marked field can be protected from loosing its value during if the value of is true.
Specific merge algorithms for application types can be performed by using derived implementations of this class.

member.name: F:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger.protectOverwrite
member.summary: Controls if fields of persistent classes marked with [ObjectMergerProtectOverwrite] will be protected from overwriting during the merge.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Constructs a new ObjectMerger instance.
member.param: If set to true, all fields of the persistent classes can be overwritten regardless of the attribute usage.
member.remarks: The field will be computed by the parameter value.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger.ProtectOverwrite(System.Object)
member.summary: Callback determining if the [ObjectMergerProtectOverwrite] attribute should be obeyed for the given object.
member.param: The object of the source context to check.
member.returns: Default implementation returns the value of the field .
member.remarks: This callback is used by the merge process to determine is overwrite protection needs to be done for the .

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger.CleanObject(Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo,Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.IObjectMergerContext)
member.summary: Callback for merging an object of the source context with the state 'CLEAN'.
member.remarks: Default implementation will resolve the object in the target context.
member.param: Information for the object to be handled.
The merge context information.
member.returns: true if successful, false otherwise
member.exception: Corresponding destination context object could not be accessed (already deleted, locked, ...)

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger.NewObject(Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo,Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.IObjectMergerContext)
member.summary: Callback for merging an object of the source context with the state 'NEW'.
member.remarks: Default implementation will create a new instance in the target context and NOT perform
member.param: Information for the object to be handled.
The merge context information.
member.returns: true if successful, false otherwise

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger.UpdateObject(Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo,Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.IObjectMergerContext)
member.summary: Callback for merging an object of the source context with the state 'DIRTY'.
member.remarks: Default implementation will resolve the target object and perform .
member.param: Information for the object to be handled.
The merge context information.
member.returns: true if successful, false otherwise
member.exception: Corresponding destination context object could not be accessed (already deleted, locked, ...)

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger.CopyObjectContent(Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo,Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.IObjectMergerContext)
member.summary: Callback for copying the values of an object of the source context into the corresponding destination context's object.
member.remarks: Default implementation will overwrite the target context's object with the values from the source context, obeying the setting.
member.param: Information for the object to be handled.
The merge context information.
member.returns: true if successful, false otherwise
member.exception: Transitively required object in the destination context could not be accessed (already deleted, locked, ...)

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMerger.DeleteObject(Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.ObjectMergeInfo,Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.IObjectMergerContext)

The merge context information.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.OID.SingleFieldIdentity
member.summary: Abstract base class for all single field identity implementations.
member.remarks:
A common case of single field identity uses exactly one persistent field from the class to represent identity. In such cases a prefactured single field identity can be used instead of creating a new user-defined class for identity purposes. To enable single field identity for a persistent class only the name of the identifying field must be specified, see example.
An instance of this class can be obtained with from a persistent instance or parsed by from the key string representation.
An instance of this class can be used with to obtain the persistent object this instance is refering to.
All implementations of the single field identity class are serializable, Xml serializable, return the key value in string representation as the result of ToString() and behave correctly wrt. Equals()/GetHashCode().
The name given to the parameter is checked during enhancement. The concrete type used for identity is derived from the type of the single identity field.
Currently only certain field types are supported: System.String, System.Guid, System.Char, System.Byte, System.Int16, System.Int32, System.Int64. If a non-supported type is used, the enhancer will issue an error.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.PersistentClassesRegistry.registerAuthorizedStateManagerClass(System.Object)
member.summary: Register a class authorized to replaceStateManager. The caller of this method must be authorized for JDOPermission("setStateManager"). During replaceStateManager, a persistence-capable class will call the corresponding checkAuthorizedStateManager and the class of the instance of the parameter must have been registered.
member.param: a Class that is authorized for JDOPermission("setStateManager").
member.throws: SecurityException if the caller is not authorized for JDOPermission("setStateManager").

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.PersistentClassesRegistry.checkAuthorizedStateManager(Telerik.OpenAccess.SPI.dataobjects.StateManager)
member.summary: Check that the parameter instance is of a class that is authorized for JDOPermission("setStateManager"). This method is called by the replaceStateManager method in persistence-capable classes. A class that is passed as the parameter to replaceStateManager must be authorized for JDOPermission("setStateManager"). To improve performance, first the set of authorized classes is checked, and if not present, a regular permission check is made. The regular permission check requires that all callers on the stack, including the persistence-capable class itself, must be authorized for JDOPermission("setStateManager").
member.param: an instance of StateManager whose class is to be checked.

member.name: T:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction
member.summary:
The JDO Transaction interface provides for initiation and completion of transactions under user control. It is a sub-interface of the {@link PersistenceManager} that deals with options and transaction demarcation.
Transaction options include whether optimistic concurrency control should be used for the current transaction, whether instances may hold values in the cache outside transactions, and whether values should be retained in the cache after transaction completion. These options are valid for both managed and non-managed transactions.
Transaction initiation and completion methods have similar semantics to javax.transaction.UserTransaction when used outside a managed environment. When used in a managed environment, transaction initiation and completion methods may only be used with bean-managed transaction semantics.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.isActive
member.summary: Returns whether there is a transaction currently active.
member.returns: true if the transaction is active.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.getNontransactionalRead
member.summary: If true, allows persistent instances to be read without a transaction active.
member.returns: the value of the nontransactionalRead property

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.setNontransactionalRead(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If true, allow persistent instances to be read without a transaction active. If an implementation does not support this option, a JDOUnsupportedOptionException is thrown.
member.param: the value of the nontransactionalRead property

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.getNontransactionalWrite
member.summary: If true, allows persistent instances to be written without a transaction active.
member.returns: the value of the nontransactionalWrite property

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.setNontransactionalWrite(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If true, allow persistent instances to be written without a transaction active. If an implementation does not support this option, a JDOUnsupportedOptionException is thrown.
member.param: the value of the nontransactionalRead property

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.getRetainValues
member.summary: If true, at commit time instances retain their field values.
member.returns: the value of the retainValues property

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.setRetainValues(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If true, at commit instances retain their values and the instances transition to persistent-nontransactional. If an implementation does not support this option, a JDOUnsupportedOptionException is thrown.
member.param: the value of the retainValues property

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.getRestoreValues
member.summary: Return the current value of the restoreValues property.
member.returns: the value of the restoreValues property

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.setRestoreValues(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
If true, at rollback, fields of newly persistent instances are restored to their values as of the beginning of the transaction, and the instances revert to transient. Additionally, fields of modified instances of primitive types and immutable reference types are restored to their values as of the beginning of the transaction.
If false, at rollback, the values of fields of newly persistent instances are unchanged and the instances revert to transient. Additionally, dirty instances transition to hollow. If an implementation does not support this option, a JDOUnsupportedOptionException is thrown.
member.param: the value of the restoreValues property

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.getOptimistic
member.summary: Optimistic transactions do not hold data store locks until commit time.
member.returns: the value of the Optimistic property.

member.name: M:Telerik.OpenAccess.RT.Transaction.setOptimistic(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Optimistic transactions do not hold data store locks until commit time. If an implementation does not support this option, a JDOUnsupportedOptionException is thrown.
member.param: the value of the Optimistic flag.
